The answers are simple. The First possibility-(Answer #1) We are alone
and we are the only life in the entire universe/multiverse. (I'm sure
this hypothesis makes Bible-thumpers, narcissists who are threatened
with the idea that they we are not the only game in town, and people
with fragile egos very happy. Your Welcome!!) (Answer #2) We are not
alone and there is plenty of intelligent life in the universe, but this
intelligence in particular, is no better than human intelligence.
Unfortunately, our type of intelligence might be the pinnacle form of
intelligence in the entire universe. (That is a scary thought, maybe
even worse than the thought of us being alone!!)Thus, just like for
humans, interstellar travel is also too "hard" for all other lifeforms
as well. Just like with humans they also suffer from corrupt leadership,
and just like us they also don't have the collective will to overcome a
myriad of personality disorders that stifle advancement and will
eventually be their undoing. Furthermore, we have yet to figure out how
to travel anywhere close to a decent percentage of the speed of
light.(Not that the "powers that be" plan on putting necessary resources
towards cracking that code anytime soon.) So what makes anyone think
that any other human like intelligent species can pull off what us
humans probably never will? (Wishful thinking much? We are talking about
humans here! We can't even agree on global warming let alone invest in
the long term survival of our species!) (Answer #3) Super-intelligent
alien life does exist but they have not visited us yet. Why? Because we
are beneath them. If I was a super-intelligent alien I would not visit
us either because we are soooo basic. When is the last time you rolled
out the red carpet for the flies that infested your outdoor garbage can?
From the perspective of advanced life, we humans are just too basic.
They have seen our kind all over the universe many times before and they
are just not that impressed. (Answer #4) We are not alone, and the
universe is teaming with life! Unfortunately that life is nowhere near
as intelligent as humans are (Again, a very disturbing thought!!) The
vast majority of alien life is probably microbial, or in the best case
scenario, no more intelligent than dolphins, apes, crows, dogs, cats,
octopus, etc. If this is indeed the case, then that, in my opinion,
WOULD BE AWESOME!! Relatively dim-witted space creatures for the win!!
This would mean that human-like higher intelligence is soooo freaking
rare that we are literally the only beings who have it in the entire
universe. (That would be a sad commentary indeed!!) Too bad our
incompetent species will never get a chance to travel beyond our solar
system and see any of these cool relativity dim-witted space creatures
due to our species collective self destructive tendencies. :(

I think that civilisations wiping out themselves with nukes is out of question. We know for sure that there was no civilisation on earth before us which would have destroyed itself with nuclear weapons, otherwise archeologists would have discovered it long ago. Which means, even if we manage to destroy ourselves with nukes, and even if every single human dies, there are still 0 chances that all life including bacteria will be destroyed. And sooner or later it will evolve to a similar state to ours, but this time it will be prepared: it will know what mistakes we made by examining our remains. Of course, there are other obstacles on the way, let's say the new civilisation gets wiped out by a giant meteorite, and by the time life evolves again, our sun explodes. But that doesn't mean it happens to every single planet out there. If life exists on millions of planets, thousands should be able to suvive. What I think is more probable is that, considering the amount of time required for life to evolve, the window of opportunity for contact is so small, that different civilisations never match in time. Either that, or interstellar travel the way we imagine it is impossible entirely, we just don't know it yet.
Speaking of interstellar travel, if the scale of things is so enormous that traveling to another star with the current tech would take millions of years, I wonder why do we even bother thinking about sending humans? Why not send bacteria or some other primitive forms of life instead.

I think it's possible people are overestimating the number of worlds that could host life - as we know it, at least.

Our sun is a single star; most stars are in binary or larger systems. That makes things interesting for any planets trying to survive, let alone produce life. Saturn and Jupiter are locked, which prevented them from migrating closer to the Sun. Jupiter's gravity makes it more difficult for really big things to hit the Earth, increasing our odds. The Moon is tidally locked to Earth, which stabilizes the planet's tilt. If our planet wobbled like Mars does, the polar ices caps would be melting and reforming elsewhere as Earth flopped around, with the poles now pointing in some random direction.

In short, we have a really nice planet to evolve on!

The solution to the Fermi Paradox is that there is no paradox. A little math and common sense suggests its whole premise is invalid and in fact, the exact opposite must be true.

The odds of us finding an alien species are akin to the odds that two microbes on specks of sand at opposite ends of the Sahara Desert will ever cross paths. Actually, given the true scale of the universe, the microbes have a better chance than we do.

And that’s only considering the physical size of the cosmos. Then there’s the time scale. Once you try to grasp just how staggeringly long “billions of years” really is, you quickly realize It’s more likely that countless advanced civilizations have risen and fallen across space long before we ever first scratched on a cave wall. And it’s equally likely that countless more will spring up long after we’re gone.

Fermi’s Paradox is rooted in a basic inability of the human mind to properly comprehend the sheer size and age of the universe. Seen from that scale, we are much smaller than the microbes on a single speck of desert sand, and the entire history of our existence spans less time than it takes the universe to blink.

There could be cosmically-visual evidence of star-spanning aliens right this second on the other side of the Milky Way. If so, our most powerful telescopes won't be able to see that evidence for another 100,000 years! And of course by then, both the aliens and us could easily be extinct. Let's not even begin to think about what hyper-advanced alien civilizations existed 10 million, 100 million years, or 1 billion years ago that we'll have no way to ever know about.

It's pretty much mathematically impossible that we're the "first" or "unique" among developed alien life in the universe. Unfortunately, it's equally mathematically impossible that we'll ever co-exist close enough in time and space to see, hear, or otherwise communicate with them in anyway. In that sense, for all intents and purposes, we are in all probability "alone" in the universe (so we'd better figure out how to get our species right). A bit of a bummer I admit, until you remember that human beings are pretty damn incredible all by themselves. And THAT’s the actual answer. But y’know… sci-fi is fun to think about too. 😁

나는 외계 문명에 대하여도 인문학적 접근 방식이 필요하다고 생각합니다. 외계 생명체의 사고 방식과 정신적 특성 등이 과연 인간과 비슷할까 하는 의문을 가져 보아야 합니다. 이 과정에서 인문학적 지식뿐만 아니라 과학적 지식도 요구되는데 이 방식으로 요구되는 과학적 지식의 필요성은 인문학적 접근 방식에 포함된다고 생각합니다.
예를 들어, 인간은 생체적인 고통을 느끼면 그 고통에 대한 불쾌감을 느끼고 고통에서 벗어나기를 희망합니다. 그런데 만약 외계 생명체가 생체적인 고통을 느끼는 생물학적 기제가 없어서 인간과는 많이 다른 감정 메커니즘을 가진다면 그 외계 문명은 인간의 문명과 어떻게 다를 것인가 하는 문제를 생각해 볼 때, 생물학적인 지식이 필요하고 이 지식은 외계 문명에 대한 인문학적 접근 방식에 포함됩니다.
이런 식으로 외계 문명에 대한 사고 방식을 넓혀 가다 보면 외계에 대한 정확한 정보가 없는 상태에서는 어떠한 결론도 쉽사리 지을 수 없다는 사실을 깨닫게 됩니다.
그럼 저는 또 다른 생각을 하게 됩니다. 그렇다면 인류가 지구에 찾아온 외계 문명을 처음 접한다면 어떤 일이 벌어질까? 이때 외계 문명이 뭐시기 3단계 전후라고 가정해 봅시다. 이 상황에서는 지구 내의 국가간 외교 정치 정세도 고려해 보아야 합니다. 외계 문명이 지구 내의 강대국이라 판단하는 미국과 중국에만 일차적 교류를 진행한다면 인류보다 뛰어난 기술력을 지닌 외계 생명체들의 의지에 따라 세계 대전이 또 일어날 수도 있습니다. 아니면 미국과 중국의 기술력이 급격히 증가하면서 외계 생명체들의 의지와는 무관하게 그 두 국가를 중심으로 냉전 체제가 다시 발생할 수도 있겠죠.
만약 인류의 기술력을 한참 초월한 외계 문명의 기술이 지구상의 인류에게 긍정적인 절차를 통해 공개된다면, 인간들은 과학 기술의 발전이 불러올 윤리적 문제들을 아예 무시하며 과학 기술을 무자비하게 발전시킬 것입니다. 외계 문명과의 교류에서 오는 기하급수적인 기술 발전의 가능성을 놓치기 싫은 마음과 저 외계 문명에게 종속되기 싫어 하는 마음때문입니다. 이러한 이유들로 무자비하게 과학기술만 발전시킨다면 뛰어난 외계 문명의 긍정적인 접근은 오히려 인류의 보존에 있어 부정적인 결과를 가져올 가능성이 큽니다. 반대로 외계 문명이 처음부터 인류에 좋지 않은 목적을 가지고 접근했다면 더 말할 것도 없지요. 저는 이와 같은 이유로 인류보다 더 발전된 기술력을 가지고 있는 외계 문명과의 접촉은 최대한 피해야 한다고 생각합니다. 아니면 이런 외계 문명과의 접촉이 있더라도 미국의 51구역의 소문처럼 극비리에서 진행되어야 한다고 생각합니다. 아마 인류의 문명을 초월한 외계 문명에 저와 같은 가치관이 널리 퍼져 있어서 그들이 스스로를 숨기느라 인류가 외계 문명을 발견하지 못 하고 있는 것은 아닐까요? ㅎㅎ

Okay...I have a solution for the Fermi Paradox that I have not heard at all...but it's so simple.

Eyes. I think us humans assume when we think of alien life that they will have eyes like most creatures here on earth.

Have we ever considered how rare it may be for eyes to evolve. Without, how can any creature observe the stars above and grow a curiosity to travel and explore.
There may be eyes, with less visuals than us, or perhaps other forms of environment detection evolved on other planets that do not require light or eyes for alien creatures to evolve and get to a point of being Intelligent beings.

It's a simple but adequate solution that I never heard discussed. It's almost baffling to me.

With a clever use of the Drake's equation, they found out that the Milky Way harbors probably 12 sentient species with high technology.
Think about it: 12 civilizations in a galaxy of 100 billion stars.
Even if they were really there, they would much probably explore their neighborhood before venturing towards the great unknown.
How much time a civilization - or 12 of them - evolved enough to achieve FTL flight through the galaxy could take to viit every single planet? Probably they wouldn't visit a new world every day or even every month, so, they would much probably take TOO long to visit every world in our galaxy, am I right?
Now, tell me: how much time they would need to visit every single planet TWICE?
100 billion stars and 12 civilizations... Let's suppose they can visit all the planet of the galaxy within an optimistic 1 million year. That means that if they visit Earth today, they probably will return only 1 million years in the future. Space is so big and things are so scarcely scattered that even with technology, time and whatever is needed, it would be almost impossible to meet an alien by accident. And probably if they were found wandering around our Solar System, that would mean they are alread all around us and we are surrounded by them.
And maybe we are.
We never left our stellar neighborhood. We may think our telescopes and radiotelescopes and probes are smart, but think: we barely see beyond Neptune with our telescopes, and except by strong sources of radiation like stars, we can't actually SEE anything. If a spaceship was flying around Jupiter, we could know because we have probes there - but if the aliens were making a drag racing of UFOs around Uranus we probably would miss them. We think we are smart, but sometimes I think even the astronomers underestimate the size of Universe.
Maybe the aliens are out there, all around, and we will only find out when accidentally find one - or maybe we are the first sentient creatures and the Universe out there is fully empty. Maybe intelligent life needs more than 13 billion years of lucky chemical reactions and natural selection to flourish, maybe our existence is so rare that we are the very first to ask these questions, but... It is kinda sad think about the Univese as a huge void...

My guesses:
1. Interstellar travel is REALLY hard. FTL is impossible just like Einstein predicted. Sub-light speed travel requires enormous amount of redundancy due to random collisions with interstellar dust and cosmic rays.
2. There is really no point to interstellar travel. All star system are ultimately made up of the same materials. Whatever is there is also here. Population growth slows or even becomes negative eventually once a species discovers birth control. Even if you ran out of space on the surface of your planet, living underground or in orbit is much easier than trying to travel interstellar distances. You can build better and better telescopes and just observe what's there without ever having to go there.
3. Dark Forest hypothesis: Everyone is paranoid and tries to remain hidden (I actually think it is UNLIKELY that "Reapers" are killing everyone in sight; they have no incentive to wait until a civ "reveals" itself. If they already made up their mind that all other life forms must be extinguished, they have had all the time in the universe to look in every cranny and find us).
4. Intelligent life actually is very rare. The galaxy is big but finite. The core regions may well be wholly inhabitable. Some of the bottlenecks we have been through and will likely face in the future, e.g. meteor strikes, plagues, climate change, nuclear apocalypse, AI apocalypse, etc, have very low probability of survival. When you start multiplying very small numbers with each other (conditional probabilities), the answer to the Drake equation very quickly becomes <1. Now, it may seem unjustified to assume we are "special" but that is only true from a bird's eye view. Given that we exist and taking that as a Bayesian prior, it is credible to posit that intelligent life may be very rare.

Fun fact regarding ‘type 2’ civilizations:
Even the possibility of capturing the entire power output of a star requires 2 things that make it incredibly unlikely.
1. More matter than exists in a single solar system.
2. The ability to convert that matter into any other type of matter needed at zero energy cost.

You don’t become a ‘Type 2’ civilization by building a Dyson sphere.
You demonstrate that you’re a ‘Type 3’ civilization by building a Dyson sphere around someone else’s star, to exterminate them, even though it would be less costly to simply ‘glass’ every celestial body they have colonized.

the main problem with these two videos is it doesn't understand the Fermi-paradox and breaks it explaining the reasons for it. The whole morse code thing is stupid and just screams, "I dont understand Fermi"... The paradox ISNT explained by non-realistic answers to actual factual problems. You cant suggest the laws of the Universe dont exist to explain a real paradox.  Its like saying, If there are 1.5 billion cellphones in use on Earth, why isnt there more warp drive signatures?  Fermi states a FACT.. (If)There ARE 11 million intelligent civilizations in the Milky Way, why cant we detect them. The answer cannot be..they are dead. WHY.. because the statement of fact in the question has them alive. Fermi successfully predicted the number of Chimney Sweepers by knowing the  number of chimneys needed sweeping .. ignoring stupid non-facts like the number of chimneys NOT in existence or the number of Chimney Sweepers who died years ago. If you take a disk 100,000 LYRs wide by 10,000 LYRS high and RANDOMLY spread 11 million ALIVE civilizations inside it.. there is NO way any single civilization doesnt know of at least 3 others, the average number being around 6 civilizations known.  THIS is the paradox. You take ALL THE FACTS we KNOW.. that we KNOW.. are true about the Universe and Physics and there MUST BE about 11 MILLION civilizations out there RIGHT NOW... Where ARE they?

Interestingly, the idea that we are the center of the universe works on smaller scales as well. We believe our nation is all that matters. We believe our state or city is all that matters. All the way down to believing our immediate family is all that matters. I think this is simply a matter of reducing mental load. It's not that we don't care about bigger things, it's that we don't need to care about them at this very moment. When the time comes for something beyond Earth to be considered, we'll concern ourselves with it as needed. When you think about it, it's a rather interesting mental mechanism to be able to switch on or off the "bigger picture" as needed without even noticing, and one has to wonder if it is something every species would share. Could you imagine ALWAYS thinking on a grand scale? It would be overwhelming.

My own thinking goes like this:
We can entangle photons or even electrons with each other. Their changes can be seen instantaneously even from long distances. Then calculate how many of these entanglements have happened on big bang and after it. If aliens finds these, then they may use them as a tool of communication without any delay. This is the only thing that we know that may be used instant messaging from all around universe (well some relays stations needed to the more distant parts). And these messages are completely secure (as far as we know). Think about sending any electromagnetic wave message to Sun, it takes over 8 mins, to the nearest star it takes 4 years, on the other side of Milkyway it takes 100 000 years and so on. Instant messaging is needed to get reasonable communication. Because entangled particles may disrupt atoms and may even cause larger harm, over wast distances, then it is likely that intelligent species are controlling the usage. So we just need to find if any historically entangled particles could be found and if they are connected to the universal communication grid. This may lead to the communications with intelligent species around the entire universe.

At this point we have also reached a technological limit that allows us to join other intelligent species. It could be a border that is used as a needed threshold of making any communications.

By this way we may find a fast communication network around the universe or if it is silent, then we may just use it for our own means.

Life on other worlds doesn't mean intelligence. In the entire history of this planet, only one species developed to even conceive of the existence of other beings somewhere else. If most of the dinosaurs hadn't been wiped out, who knows if intelligence of that sort would ever had evolved? There's also the fact it took a lot of wars for our technology to reach this level. A planet that doesn't support the kind of population growth that led to those wars, might never get beyond hunter/gatherer. If they don't suffer ice ages and warming at the right times, who knows what course evolution might take?

We've already hit a practical technological wall when it comes to air travel. We CAN build supersonic passenger planes, but the fuel efficiency is much lower than planes that travel a little below the speed of sound. Their design requires the plane to be more narrow, meaning they carry fewer passengers. Add in the internet and video conferencing and there's not much reason for planes to go that fast outside military use. Interstellar travel is full of such walls, not the least of which is that we'd likely never know if the mission was successful.

The idea of self replicating probes (or the death fleet in this video) presupposes that systems with life would have the raw materials in sufficient amounts for the probe to self replicate and transfer it's data. For example, what if the planet were one big ocean?

A key component to how we look for alien life is based on our radio transmissions from the 60’s.

But our communications have improved since then.

If you went to Alpha Centauri and pointed a radio telescope at Earth today, you would not detect the “intelligent radio signals” and conclude there is no life on earth.

This needs to factor into the equation but is left out.

Plus while the universe is very old. Much of the early history was mass fusing together in stars to become the heavier elements. So it took time for planets to start forming. Let alone planets with the elements needed for complex life.

As such out of all Earth like planets that have ever existed and ever will exist. We’re only 4-6% into the universe lifespan of creating planets that can support life as we know it.

This needs to be part of the equation but isn’t.

And finally, space is big. Really big. And we can only look at the tiniest fraction at a time. Even now we’re still discovering many things in areas we’ve been looking at for many years and are far from even a base scan of the visible universe.

This needs to be factored in. But isn’t. The Fermi Paradox isn’t actually a paradox at all. But a hubris thought experiment that concludes only one thing.

Humans are special, first, and greatest. And that we haven’t seen other life proves it.

And that’s flawed thinking.

Warning, long post ahead, only read if you want to semi-assuage your existentialism this video may have unintentionally given (but its still a great video nonetheless, honestly I’ve loved this channel for years so nothing but love and light and kudos to the Kurz. Team; y’all are awesome with how you make these ideas so easily accessible and your adorable animations!! 🤩) ...



Many people in spiritual circles will be the first to tell you that the next Great Awakening is coming. The Age of Aquarius. Religion, spirituality, politics, culture, metaphysics, science fiction...they’re all more entertained than initially thought. Everything in the universe is relative, we are all relative to one another, whether we like it or not.

We can try to classify ourselves with economic classes or national borders, but whether we like it or not, we are all just one living beating human race. We’re all like blood vessels and this earth we inhabit, this rock we call home is the organ we give life to. The earth, Mother Gaia if you will, gives us existence and resources and sustenance, in return we give her a purpose for existing.

So hypothetically, if an alien race were to use our planet for resources, it’d be pointless for them to kill us squirrels. It’s always been my belief that culture and technological advancement are contingent on one another. Great power is only awarded with great responsibility (and whatnot :). 

A caveman is brutal and easily kills his fellow caveman for meat, resources, shelter. Yet he’s just caveman. He can’t do much harm. The most vile creatures will always be countered by either fate or another equal power, in my opinion. 

Or, I’m not a heavy history buff but the Renaissance. everyone knows about that era of human history. Wasn’t it like a time marked by **both great cultural and technological advancement? Or better yet the second half of the 20th century? It was an era that saw leaps in both our understanding of space, technology, nuclear weaponry, and human rights. Carl Sagan, Nelson Mandela, the bombing of Hiroshima, Malcom X, Stonewall, Reagan, Hitler, Bob Ross, RBG, Marsha P Johnson etc etc. The list goes on. I’m not saying these people/events are good or bad, but I mention them because they represent the great leaps in our understanding of both theoretical thought and humanity in the last 50 years only. Gorbachev, Princess Diana, Mother Teresa, the Popes...the Beatles, Queen, Jane Goodall, Ellen, 9/11, Pixar movies, the fall of the Berlin Wall, the DMZ between the two Koreas etc etc etc. 

Culture is contingent on politics, politics on technological advancement, technological advancement dependent on the growth of humanity. Once we realize that all these things are and will always be relative, then that can probably assuage everyone’s squirrel fears in this little comments section.  We, humans, created the deadliest most devastating nuclear weapons once, dropped it twice and by some miracle in the heavens,,have not used them since. We, collectively, as a human race are terrified of the devastation it could bring. And that’s the beauty of evolution. As we all collectively grow smarter, we inevitably grow more sentient. The two forces work in beautiful tandem. imagine, hypothetically of course, if cavemen had access to nuclear weaponry..hehe lol.

And now back to aliens...the stars of everything right now at the moment. I personally searched up this video because I did spot a ufo a few weeks ago. but that’s besides the point.

Aliens. If there even was such a powerful enough civilization, strong enough to wipe us clean, you don’t think they’d be a bit more sentient themselves? Culture and advancement are dependent on one another. The two facets of society also probably love each one another a lot too. They build off the other. Feminine and masculine energies. Yin and yang. Art,beauty,family,love,aesthetics + advancement,technology,politics,work,practicality. They balance each other out, perhaps this is a universal sentiment all across the universe...it’s the most fundamental sentiment there is in my opinion.

So, if there was a higher, as you put it, a more “advanced” civilization out there...aliens. Do you guys really think they’d be mindless brutes...hell if they wanted to use our resources on here wouldn’t they have done so by now? If they had the power to wipe us out easily, they also have the power to infiltrate our society, meet our puppies, watch our sunsets, meet our children, learn our culture, learn our hopes, dreams, fears and wishes....and as any advanced society would know, a clear conscience probably weighs much more than a couple of logs and an ocean lol.

I’m optimistic. I think we underestimate higher life forms, if they even do exist. And ~~hypothetically~~ let’s just say a higher alien force just one day said “screw it, we need those forests and also their sun”, well it’s not like we would know and its not like we’d even be able to stop them anyways (not trying to sound morbid but its the honest truth). Or An asteroid could hit us, the sun could explode, the rain could endlessly pour from the sky like in the biblical times... it’s why regardless, we should never ever ever take a single day for granted. The pandemic taught all of us that too. The probability of Yellowstone erupting and instantaneously destroying all life within the US is just as likely as —god forbid—a family member of mine getting into a car accident. Dear Lord what a thought. So whether aliens get bored with us and just instantly wipe us out, or some other awful disaster occurs, we must always remember these proverbs, found and reiterated in nearly every single ancient text and every white mom’s home goods wall plate and those are

Always be grateful and never take what you have for granted,
Carry with you pure intentions in your heart,
Love and light above all else,
The universe is not chaos; take care to trust in God/allah/buddah/source,,,but always trust that there is something higher out there,
And because you followed that last step, now you can have faith in knowing that everything in life will always be balanced out and everything will always work out for the highest good of all. Do not worry about anything. Just take care and be a good person.

Namaste, love and light,

The Fermi Paradox is just another hair-brained human theory, devised by a lunatic without a single clue regarding extraterrestrial visitation. It isn't a "theory," but a rerun of one of those 1950's "flying saucer" movies, with goggle-eyed green monsters with designs on taking over planet earth. This monumental idiot has obviously never heard of Roswell, or any of the dozens more series of crashed UFO events on earth to date.
As far as "communication" goes, MATHEMATICS is the single language that connects virtually every advanced civilization that I know of, which outside of pure psychic, mind-to-mind communication, is the single best way to relate with our alien counterparts. Which brings me to the subject of SETI, the dopey "make work" project that has wasted BILLIONS OF DOLLARS FOR NOTHING, never finding even ONE intelligent message from deep space in over 40-years. Here are my two simple reasons for this:
1) Aliens are ALREADY HERE, and have been for probably centuries, or longer. Just look up.
2) Why would any super advanced civilization be using outdated, 200-year old radio technology to contact other worlds in the first place, particularly when they possess the technology to navigate hundreds of thousands of light years of interstellar space in seconds??
As far as this dead guy's other frail fantasies are concerned, he made up his entire 'Paradox' hypothesis in 1950, 71-years ago, but he might as well have made it in the Stone Age. He wouldn't know quantrum physics from a black hole, except for the massive black hole between his EARS. If I am incorrect, and aliens beings AREN'T visiting planet earth, what have the hundreds of millions of earthlings been looking at all these centuries?? "Flocks of birds," "swamp gas," and "light reflecting off the planet Venus"??? This is sheer nonsense, and government groups as diverse as the CIA, the FBI, the US Army, the US Air Force, and the Department of Naval Affairs have known about unknown alien spacecraft since at least 1947.

Time is the biggest (literally) denominator, then space (distance). The universe is very old and yes, we might have missed out on trillions of life forms already. Those that exist today might simply be out of reach; by the time we could reach one another, the other side might've died out already. Or in other words, if we left to some interesting-looking planet today (devoid of life) it might have an intelligent society by the time we arrive. Besides all that: someone needs to be the first intelligent lifeform. Even if it's very unlikely to be us, it might be us.

In that case, we are all alone. And the future (time) is probably a near-infinite amount of time. In which trillions of intelligent societies might come into existence.

I'm choosing to believe that we have reached peak technological prowess already, and humanity (or what remains of it) is actually tens of thousands of years more advanced than the time we currently "live" in. We are just in a simulation of our own choosing. Each and every one of us is part of a simulation that has a limited set of rules. Many trillions of humans choose to live entire lives in different times. Some choose to be Caesar himself, some are Mozart, some are Nazi generals, some are the firstborn Martian, some are Elon Musk, some just have a regular life, born in the 1980s, dying around 2060.

Maybe that's where the afterlife comes from. It's another option. We can live in whatever we think heaven might be like, or we can go through a computer-assisted (in the form of screens or in the form of a God or angel assisting us) set of choices to shape our next life.

e.g. You die, you get a config screen. "In what timezone would you like to live your next life?" - I want to be born in 2230. "Do you wish to be a specific human from this era?" - Show me a list of the most influential people. I pick that one. "Do you wish to change their gender and looks? - Sure, make them look like [..]. - "Here is a timeline of the suggested life, do you want to make any changes?" - Yes, make sure that this person invests in a startup company named Greepledeeple in 2242 and make sure this nets them a profit of $4 trillion 2 years later. "Done, any other requests?" - Hmm, yeah... can we add an alien invasion in the year 2251? - "It is not part of any historically accurate timeline, but we'll create a new instance of the universe just for you. Anything else?" - I want to be the general of humanity's defenses, and I want to be the savior of the human species. I shall never be physically harmed. That's all. - "Done. Enjoy your next life."

Mathematically...the fact that any life exists on this year, much less the amount of diverse life and intelligent life, is a mathematical impossibility.
I'm not saying it isn't possible, I'm saying that the odds of life forming by random chance far exceed the what is considered possible mathematically. Yes, I am a degreed and practicing mathematician for those wondering.
You may say, well give enough time!!! And yes, you would be correct. But as this video points out the universe is very old, about 13.8 billion or so and even that isn't enough time to over come the mathematical impossibility that we, or any life at all, exists.
So, the fact that we do exist(and even still the diverse life we have on this planet) means this mathematical impossibility was defied boldly on this planet. I can't imagine it happening a second time...unless something is causing it to happen, which would tip the odds considerably.
You might think ALIENS MADE US!!! And you would likely be horrifically wrong...as no only would they also have to defy the mathematical impossibility, but they would have to have done it significantly faster than we did as they were here first and they would have to have done it long enough ago to travel to this planet and create us and leave without a trace.

This...this reason is why I can't believe and never will believe in aliens.

There is currently no such thing as human civilization. Space travel, artificial intelligence and a unified planet as we currently conceive of these things, are nothing but the fantasies and mythology of Western civilization. We only perceive these as universal values because Western society has dominated much of the world for the past 400 years. Only a civilization that is in full ownership and appreciation for the things that make us human such as spirituality, conflict and synchronicity with nature, all while embracing science as a tool and not a master will take us to the stars. I think as long as we can imagine more advanced technology and just lack the knowledge to build it, the limit of technology is not reached.

Look at Star Trek: In the late 80's/90's they showed the usage of Tablets. It was SciFi back then and the "Science Fiction" pretty fast became just "Science" by the Mid 2000's with the arrival of the first tablets on the Market, but these things were thought off already 10-20 years earlier.

Another example: FTL drives.
We can't build them right now, but we know, what we need to achieve to build them in theory, e.g. a way to shrink the energy usage of a FTL drive from something, that would consume a whole star to something that could be powered by a reactor and materials and means to protect the ship and the crew within.

And since we don't know right now, how to do it practically, our physicists keep thinking of ways to get there and will keep doing it.

So as long as we have something to strive for, there is no limit.

And some day we might get to the point, where we could realize more sophisticated ideas of SciFi-Series, e.g. in Star Trek they reignited a dead star. Maybe we could do such stuff for real some time, so this "All stars die and the universe gets dark"-ending of the Universe never happens?
Or maybe we travel to alternate dimensions? Or create a new universe to live in?

Because space is huge.

Even if there are a thousand advanced space faring civilizations in our galaxy....we would probably never detect any of them.

There are about 100 Billion stars in our Galaxy so only one out of 100,000,000 stars would have a civilization.

The average distance between these civilizations would be about 2,000 light years.

And that's if there were 1,000 civilizations.

Then you factor in the time delay.

If there's an advanced civilization 10,000 light years away we would only be able to detect them 10,000 years after the fact.
So they could literally be transmitting strong radio signals for the last 9,000 years and it will still be 1,000 years before we detect them.

So not only are we limited in only being able to scan a tiny percentage of stars for radio emissions...we can only glimpse a narrow slice of the past in our own galaxy.

The problem with the Drake Equation is that the same numbers that say we are not alone ...also say that we will probably never meet them.

The problem with the idea that an interstellar civilization might have gone extinct is that few events could kill all members of a technological species spread across multiple systems. You could say that maybe another civilization killed them, but that would beg the question of where the victor is? Some sort of lovecraftian existential crisis could wipe out part of a civilization, but other branches of said civilization would be isolated and survive. Events like supernovas or gamma ray bursts can mess up a single low tech population, but not one with our level of tech or higher and certainly not one spread over many star systems. Concepts like ascension or extra universal travel could remove most of a civilization but it couldn’t remove all of it. There will inevitably be populations that stay behind due to inclination or circumstance.

I doubt that the problem is that our communications aren’t compatible either. An intelligent species is going to be watching the length and breadth of the electromagnetic spectrum, gravitational waves, and any other transmissible emissions from their galaxy, because they are still scientifically relevant. Moving on to newer tech doesn’t make you incapable of detecting or understanding lower tech signals. An irregularly variable signal is pretty much a communication by its very nature and intelligence would recognize it.

It’s possible that other species just don’t think like us. Wanderlust is, as far as we can tell, unique to humans on earth. We will brave completely inhospitable conditions just to be there. Mount Everest, the poles, and even space are all places that by all rights are not suitable for human life, but we go to these places anyway. None of these places have ever provided any resources that could make journeying to them worthwhile. We go to the hostile places just because they are there. It’s an illogical impulse, and yet we will still invest a huge amount of resources to fulfill it.

Maybe other species are happy to just live on their planet and don’t feel the desire to explore the universe like we do. Or maybe interstellar travel just isn’t worth it. It takes so long that by the time a ship reaches another star, nobody onboard will have ever experienced living on earth, and nobody on earth will even remember sending that interstellar ship. The best way to break through the Fermi paradox is to develop FTL drives so that we can actually explore the universe in a timely manner and find out what everyone else is doing for ourselves.

Do people consider that fact that everything is unfathomably far away is the reason we haven't observed any alien civilizations yet? It's not like you can look at through a telescope and view the surface a planet lightyears away. And the only method I'm aware of in trying to detect aliens is through radio broadcasts and there are a couple of things highly ineffective about that. One is radio only travels at light speed which by Earth standards is blisteringly fast but on a cosmic scale it's pretty slow. So sending out radio signals to different worlds can take decades for our nearest interstellar neighbors to hundreds, thousands millions of years for anywhere else. Also let's assume that world does have intelligent life on it. Who's to say they also have radios to pick up the broadcasts in the first place? Odds are, since humanity is extremely young in terms of the universe, any civilization we encounter will be far more advanced than we by possibly millions of years and probably have vastly different and far more sophisticated means of communicate than radio. If they even invented radio at all in their history.
I think it just comes down to our methods of trying find aliens just sucks.

Walking in the countryside today I saw a heard of cows. Cows are intelligent. They also show signs of emotion. They form herds, and they have a social hierarchy. They are cleared at an advanced state of evolution. Yet they have no technology. What if there are countless planets with species like cows, highly evolved but with no evolutionary impetus to move towards technology? Wales and dolphins are arguably more advanced. They clearly communicate in a structured way, and work collaboratively. Point is, why do we always assume that a planet with intelligent life will have anything akin to humans on it? On the only planet we currently know to have life, there are many thousands of species at varying states of evolution, yet only one with technology, and we can't even communicate with other species that live right here along side us. Why should we expect to find anything we can communicate with beyond earth? And why should that indicate we're alone in the university?

The real problem with the Fermi paradox is that it's nonsense.

Fermi paradox is bullshit. Absence of evidence is not evidence of absence. The supposition that aliens are just waiting to make contact with us is also bullshit, or aliens are just as curious about us as we are of them. The supposition that self replicating robots that would roam the universe as something other species would build is also bullshit. I don't think it makes much sense to color the universe with our biases. Just cause we want something doesn't mean that other species would feel the same way. We cannot extrapolate on intelligent life out there without having any understanding on what that life would look like, or present itself. We are still fledgling in our understanding of exoplanets and how life was created on Earth, let alone all over the universe.

99% of all life on earth has gone extinct. There a currently +/-8 million species in the planet. There were a few other human species with rudimentary societies, but now there is exactly one species that has language and science at its disposal. Intelligence and self awareness aren’t inevitable in evolution; they are, in fact, rare. We are an anomaly when contrasted with the life around us. It seems most likely to me, armchair philosopher and scientist, that the universe may be teeming with life, but that majority of it is happily swimming in seas, burrowing in soil, or running across plains, and that even something as meager as making fire, much less conquering the stars, is not in any of their futures.

The forest proposal:
1. A civilization's objective is to survive
2. A civilization's level of technology can experience a sudden leap, as humans did in the last century.
Now, imagine that an alien civilization discovered earth. Due to obvious reasons, they have no idea if we are peaceful or hostile. This cannot be resolved by communication due to the vast differences between the two worlds. If they reach out to us, then there are 2 scenarios:
Scenario 1: We're superior. It'll be game over for them.
Scenario 2: We're inferior. This seemed like good news, but all civilization could experience a great leap in technology, meaning that we will surpass their civilization and it's back to Scenario 1.
If they chose to remain silent, they will eventually be discovered by us and Game over.
Therefore, there is only 1 option left: they destroy us.
Hence, the universe is a giant forest, and each civilization is a hunter with a rifle. Each is attempting to take the others out while not being discovered themselves in a big game of Battle Royale. And right now, earth is an unarmed child standing by a giant bonfire.

4:23 I truly believe this exists somewhere. It would absolutely be what hyper-intelligent beings would do. Why allow such horrible things like depression, sorrow, pain, anger, regret, and boredom consume your life? Just upload your consciousness to your very own heaven, and exist in a constant state of bliss until the power source dies, and/or your consciousness is transported to a new star. Of course, this would require a civilization that has moved passed wars and prejudice, since such a fragile system would leave untold numbers of beings vulnerable to outside influence.

Nier: Automata actually tackled this as the possibility for humanity's future. During a prolonged alien invasion on Earth, all of mankind was wiped out. The last remaining humans uploaded their consciousnesses, along with all of the knowledge their species had accumulated over its entire existence, to a massive hard drive on the moon. Back on Earth, self-sufficient androids that were created to defeat the alien invaders and their armies of machines were left without purpose, after the aliens finally left. After humanity's extinction, the android leaders decided to formulate a lie that humans were alive and well on the moon, awaiting the war's end. This was done to give the androids a purpose, in spite of their creators leaving them behind. This begs the philosophical question of what it actually means to be "alive".

The androids were designed by humans to simulate their behaviors and emotions. As time went on, the androids' AI became more and more complex. They were evolving. The same happened with the machines the aliens left behind. They gained consciousness, becoming sentient beings. They developed feelings, personalities, attachments, faiths, and fears. One of the game's endings took it a step further and had one of the android characters send their consciousness to the same "hard drive" holding the souls of all of humanity.

This all may sound far-fetched, but imagine if we actually managed to create AI that could learn and adapt without limitations. It really isn't hard to see this as a possibility in the future. Is nature really the only thing that can create life?

Ok great, but we should look up in the night sky and see star ships and dyson spheres and other things of our imagination... but we don't and probably never have. This could mean:


A) We're alone. Either this universe was built for us (hallelujah!) or more likely, we're alone because we're a cosmic anomaly: the universe doesn't exist to make life, life just happened by accident here and the universe self-sterilizes on a regular basis with star destruction, rogue objects and gamma ray bursts. In this scenario, we probably don't have much time left and should hug our loved ones rather than read lengthy youtube comments :)


B) We are so technologically (consciously) inept that we think moving physical matter across space time is a good idea. This universe may just be our own sandbox and once we really figure out what is going on, how it actually works, how and why it was made we can come out of the dark age, make a grand unified theory and ascend. What could ascension look like when we completely master this universe? Maybe each individual will be able to think about some other distant place, some dimension or reality and just be there, perhaps sans the matter-based body.


There is a really good reason we don't receive radio waves and see starships in our telescopes and I firmly believe, the answer is much closer to B than A.

A paradox is a contradiction based on incorrect assumptions.  The fermi paradox has two assumptions: (1) alien life exists, and (2) if it exists, we'll know.  This contradicts the fact that there is no alien life that we are aware of.  There are a lot of theories going around trying to explain how alien life exists without us knowing about it, but no one wants to address the first assumption.  Those who support the idea that alien life exists want to believe it because they've already decided that the evolution of life must be so common that it must be happening everywhere, constantly.  Their entire worldview is built on that assumption, and they absolutely need it to be true in order to save their worldview.

There's one theory regarding the Fermi paradox that I quite enjoy, it's extremely simple and inspiring. The sun has existed for 4.6 billion years, Earth for 4.5 billion years. Now by comparison the Universe must be ancient right? But, it's only been around for 13 billion years. So Earth has existed for roughly 35% of the entire Universal timeline to our understanding. It doesn't make the Universe seem that old. The reason we can't see abundant life elsewhere is because no other life is sufficiently more advanced then we are. The Universe only just reached a stage where life can develop, and we are at the cutting edge of it.

We know about how the Big Bang cooled into stars and galaxies, we know about how stars form, go super nova, create light elements, go kilo nova, create heavy elements. And we know the rough timeline for these events. They are measured in millions and billions of years. But again, if the Universe is only 13 billion years then everything must be pretty young if stars take billions of years to age. The reason we don't have hyperlanes bulldozing Earth or Reapers descending to ruin life on Earth is because they don't exist yet. We, and the abundant life currently existing elsewhere are only just reaching space.

The Fermi Paradox haunts me. My solution to the Fermi Paradox is that the combination of space & time will eventually kill all life and all species. The only life that could survive a very long time is some spores and microbes. The exact reason why any somewhat intelligent life goes extinct is that either they were unaware of the danger of extinction or they were aware of their impending doom but were unable to do anything about it(in time).


The Great Filter is NOT a single event. It is an endless series of species threatening events. I classify these events as either external or internal. External events can include solar flares, asteroid impacts, etc. Internal events can include nuclear war, disease , failure to cooperate, pollution, failing to take action on known threats, etc.


Given Earth's population is fully consumed with everything except preservation of our species, I think our species(humans) is doomed. Just like most somewhat intelligent life elsewhere.


This topic forces me to re-evaluate the term "Intelligent Life". To me, the term "Intelligent Life" means that a species recognizes the threats, understands those threats and actively makes attempts to avert those all of those threats. Under this definition, we(humans) do NOT qualify as "Intelligent Life".

This is so well done but misses the point and certain facts or rather the results of investigations. I.e., we don’t know everything.

What is sure after the great meteor showers and the earth cooled, 4 billion years ago, life formed right away, apparently by natural processes. Then, for 2.5 billion years, for more generations that their are stars in the universe, simple life remained simple. It had to. The simpler the DNA, the faster it replicated and the faster it adapted to any change. It could not become complex.

Then, by some miracle of chaotic universe, one cell jumped into another and complex life became extant. This happened only once, and only once, which we know by stereo-isomers.

So long to the Cambrian explosion, so long to us, so long to who knows what.

So in all the stars of the universe, we are and may be a probability of existence of ONE. That’s all we know.

It’s most important to know what we don’t know. And to believe in God and our future.

0:00 You always say it differently and it is always bullshit. Now you say: "There are probably 10 000 stars for every grain of sand on Earth, in the observable Universe." - Please, stop making things up! The original assertion was something like this: There are approx. so many stars in the whole observable Universe as grains of sands on all the beaches of Earth. This is, of course, a very vague assertion too, because what do you consider to be a beach and how deep do you want to dig into? But now, you went to a higher level of absurdity. Now you say that there are 10 000 stars for every grain of sand of the freaking entire Earth!!! Jesus! Enough of this exaggeration! Let's make a super quick calculation, ok? There's approx. 2*10^11 galaxies in the observable Universe and there are approx. the same amount of stars in an average galaxy (maybe little less...). That means we are talking about something like 10^22 stars, ok? Now, grains of sand come in different sizes, but somewhere between 0.05mm to 4mm. Converted into volume, this is a pretty big range of volumes!!! So let say that the average size of a sand grain is around 0.5mm. That's 8 billion of them in a cube meter. Like the actual number of humans on Earth... So you need a cube of approx. 10km in size full of these 0.5mm grains of sand. So we are talking about a 2mm thick layer of sand covering the entire Earth. That's approx. how many stars are in the entire observable Universe. I think that this is much more exact than talking shit about some 10 000 stars for every grain of sand on Earth...

I have a few issues with this fermi paradox thing: Space is GIGANTIC. There are no words to tell you how freaking big it is. Light is fast but for as fast as it is, it still takes a full YEAR to go from the surface of the sun to the Oort cloud. A freaking YEAR. Not very fast sounding is it? Well that's not true. Light is really fast but this example I've given you is same for a Formula one car to cross the Earth a couple times (If anyone feels like it, do the math to figure out how many times it could in one year). Or just giving it a REALLY long racetrack. They're fast alright but it will still take time to go from point A to point B. If anyone out there is listening the signals we put out would at best be static due to the signal spreading out over time as it crosses these distances. It would be nothing more than the vacuum of space to someone who's listening. The same would go for us. We could be receiving hundreds or thousands of signals. but we detect only the equivalent of the static vacuum of space.

Another issue is the HUNDREDS of things that had to happen for our existence. Earth first had to survive creation. Then it had to survive early solar life of constant clashes of planets and meteors. THEN it had to get a moon (however it got it). THEN it also had to be the right size to achieve space travel. THEN it had to get water somehow. Then at long last it had to calm down its 6 hour day rotation to get to a slower rotation. Then it had to somehow miraculously get life. We STILL aren't even close to being done here, because THEN this life had to survive long enough to achieve multi-cellular life. Then it had to evolve into something with some kind of basic intelligence. Now i will mention that the dinosaurs were not needed for us to evolve as the only effect on our civilization was the creation of dragons and some really neat movies and some pretty cool skeletons, so we can skip this step. THEN life had to evolve some kind of grasping limb, whether it be a hand or a an advanced tentacle limb. THEN THAT SPECIFIC LIFE had to evolve into us. And this is the simple version, after all this life also had to compete with other versions of itself as well as every other life form vying for dominance. OH I FORGOT: The sun must also be formed in the habitable zone of the galaxy itself. Yeah there are that many crazy chances to NOT get us as intelligent beings. Right now we are int the step of surviving wiping ourselves out like a bunch of morons. So as cool as we all think aliens are, the odds of their existence put them at maybe ONE single plant per every 7ish galaxies I would think. Life is either unique to us, or EXTREMELY rare. To the point where our value of diamonds would be the equivalent of some random rock you find on the road.

You forgot about one other solution to the Fermi Paradox. Nearby stars are not evenly distributed. 10 million years ago our solar system was moving through a region of the Milky Way that was full of stars. Given the extreme cost of space travel, that would have been a prime time for aliens to visit us. Now we are in a region that is barren of other stars. Since our species wasn't even around yet the last time aliens probably were able to visit we probably missed their visit. Now that we are in a rather barren part of the galaxy we will have a long time to wait before we are once again within reach of aliens. "Will we be destroyed, or does a glorious futrue await us?"

Trick question. Our destruction is our glorious future.

Two big ideas often come up in discussions about the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, or SETI. One is the Drake Equation, which estimates the number of civilizations in our Galaxy whose signals we might be able to detect—potentially thousands, according to plausible estimates. The other is the so-called Fermi paradox, which claims that we should see intelligent aliens here if they exist anywhere, because they would inevitably colonize the Galaxy by star travel—and since we don’t see any obvious signs of aliens here, searching for their signals is pointless.

The Drake Equation is perfectly genuine: it was created by astronomer and SETI pioneer Frank Drake. The Fermi paradox, however, is a myth. It is named for the physicist Enrico Fermi—but Fermi never made such a claim.

I’d like to explain why the so-called Fermi paradox is mistaken, based on my deep-dive research on the topic, because this mistake has inhibited the search for E.T., which I think is worthwhile. It was cited by Sen. William Proxmire (D-WI) as a reason for killing NASA’s SETI program in 1981; the program was restarted at the urging of Carl Sagan, but was killed dead in 1993 by Senator Richard Bryan (D-NV). Since then, no searches in the U.S. have received government funds, even though thousands of new planets have been discovered orbiting stars other than our sun.

“From this distant vantage point, the Earth might not seem of particular interest. But for us, it's different. Consider again that dot.

“That's here. That's home. That’s us.

“On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every "superstar," every "supreme leader," every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there – on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.

“The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds.

“Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.

“The Earth is the only world known, so far, to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.

“It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another, and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we've ever known."

- Carl Sagan, “The Pale Blue Dot”

I would like to say that one of the major thing that we overlook while looking for life in universe is that life forms don't need to have the same/similar conditions as ours to originate or thrive.
Physics,chemistry or biology, whatever definitions,rules,principle or laws we hold so dear are not absolute universal truth for the whole universe.Just like the laws of mass and energy don't hold in quantum physics but they can't be ignored in Classic physics.
Remember,We humans concluded that we have learned whatever there is about science by the middle of 18th century and then Dalton gave his Modern Atomic Theory and the new era for science and inventions started. We can not for sure say that the only life sustainable planets are the planets who have conditions just like ours.Whatever be the reason,radiation,different gravity,different atmosphere,different type of star at the core of it's solar system,there is a possibility that different life forms can exist which do not require the same environment as ours.

We've been transmitting for like 100 years. Thats like 120 stars in that bubble of time. The odds of one of those stars having life is very low. You also have to account for the inverse square law. At that distance the signal has spread itself out to a microscopic fraction of itself. So the signal is very weak by the time it gets there. AND the aliens have to be listening for it. AND realize what it is. Or video and audio are going to be complete gibberish to them at a very fundamental machine code level as they have never seen our system before. Only our very basic pulse signals are going to be easy to figure out.

I love you Kurzgesagt but there is a small piece of misinformation in this video.
Our Milky Way contains 400 billion stars (4 x 10¹¹) and you say that its 10.000 per grain of sand on earth. That is incorrect. In the known universe there are more stars by A LOT, than grains of sand on earth, but not in Milky Way alone.

There is one other problem for space travel. Especially at the speeds required to meet other civilizations within fifty or so generations of living on the ship. Time dilation. Until we can figure out how to move uninhibited by this, we can not travel without sending off colonies who would be saying goodbye to earth, moving through time and space at such levels that even with all our tech, we can't ever hope to see them again and might as well assume they died. Personally, speaking in theory, I think the loophole would be to do what startrek did. (I think it was startrek, I might by thinking of futurama.) To make a bubble around the vessel and then move the bubble. We are holding still, everything else would be moving around us. Thus ignoring the time dilation via not moving! As to how this would be possible, no clue. If I can make any recommendations to any scientists that might possibly be reading this, I'd start looking into gravity. The way it stretches both time and space like it does is very promising! Oh boy, I can't wait to have black-hole engines!

This was an interesting question and it does have a reasonable answer. Because if you're going to be unconscious for a long time you don't want anyone walking into your megastructure and fucking with the power lines, do you? So the universe contains threats. The simplest explanation is always the potential for annihilation, so besides that, assume we can resolve that (I doubt it because it implies removing probability of any unforeseen outcome. You need to attain precognition in order to do that.)

By the time you have precognitive powers and have become Laplace's Demon you have another issue, the implications of seeing your own fate. Nothing would surprise you, because you're omniscient. And you won't ever suffer unless it was your intention to suffer, because you know exactly how to cause bliss, and can presumably induce this on yourself whenever you want it.

I think the problem is two fold; either they're too far away for us to make out their artificial signals out of natural ones (after a certain distance, all radio signals melt into noise), or the only way we'll notice them is to block out all the noise from earth. Far side lunar radio observatories seem to be the be way to eliminate at least one of these problems. The other problem is that it seems unlikely, though not impossible, that they'll have a repeating signal on long enough for us to notice, or if artificial signals would be repeating at all. So far all repeating radio signals have been pulsars of one variety or another.

The personal possible solution I subscribe to is the concept that all intelligent life has left. Not dead or non-existent, just gone.

Think about it. We humans have only been doing complex stuff for a couple thousand years. In the past hundred years, we’ve started building machines that can think, and we’re already getting close to ones that will be as smart as us. Once we do that, the machine is smart enough to keep upgrading itself, getting smarter and smarter, faster and faster. With upgrades on things like the supercollider and other experimental devices, this AI could unlock the secrets of the universe in less than a century.

Now, assuming it decides to bring us along for the ride instead of annihilating us, we could join it as we transcended all mortal concepts, advancing so quickly that the ideas of faster than light travel, the necessity of physical resources, or the desire to travel to other systems become meaningless and simple-minded in seconds.

I think that there have been a lot of civilizations, and that every civilization out there has achieved this level of transcendence. That’s why we haven’t run into any of them.

But haven't we only been looking at space for a few hundred years or so, and with really good telescopes for less than 100 yrs? And we've only seen like a billionth of a fraction of a percent of the observable universe? That's like glancing out the window of your house, seeing the neighbor's light is off, and concluding the entire town has been evacuated. There's nobody there, or we would have seen them! Seen something! Even though we admit we don't know all the rules of the universe? Or how everything works? Or even how life starts, or might work for other beings? We've seen the briefest of glances, and based it on yesterday's understanding of physics, which seems to be always advancing and upending previously held sacred truths. And how do we define the life we are searching for? Only as carbon based, water and food dependant, oxygen breathing, used to a certain level of gravity and heat and light? Are we only looking in the 'habitable zone' for beings like us? Or grey aliens with big heads, E.T., the X-files? Maybe robots or AI based on our known technology? Or is life defined as consciousness, as sentience? We could be looking in the wrong place for the wrong kind of creature. We don't know how 'life' sparked our bags of meat to consciousness, our carbon atoms arranged in the manner they are. Pick another element or 5 or 20, imagine all of the different ways they could be arranged. Imagine that there are elements, maybe buried deep in our earth's core, that we have not encountered yet despite their existence close to our own. How could these potentially interact with elements we do know, on a planet with more or less heat or gravity, an atmosphere thinner than ours, or thick and soupy (our planet's atmosphere hasn't always been conducive to human beings' survival; we couldn't have walked with the dinosaurs 250 million years ago, or existed in the atmosphere of a young earth)? We can't even survive everywhere on our own planet. We need oxygen and special clothes for our highest mountains, submersibles for the deepest ocean. We haven't even discovered every living thing on this planet, or been able to figure out how many of them live. Some creatures on earth have gills instead of lungs and can cope with pressure 7 miles under the ocean. We can't communicate with them so deny their intelligence, their sentience. And they're EARTHLINGS. I don't know how humans could cope with other non-human beings, its not in our nature to welcome foreigners, whose method of language will probably be vastly different. Who may not even have skin as we know it. And we speak of colonization as if it is an eternal, universal concept, when really only a few members of one species here has had a hard-on for it for a few thousand years. It doesn't seem insane to look objectively at one's species eventually going extinct and accepting that as simply *what happens*. Instead of trying to move heaven and earth, building rockets, charging forward with ethically ambiguous technology, all to possibly save one's species millions of years in the future. If nothing lasts forever, and we believe the entire universe will one day go dark, why fight against the inevitable? We as humans will all die, we get a few years, our descendents get a few more, species evolve, die out, their memories are lost to whatever succeeds them. We are not special, first or last. We cannot win against a catastrophic filter. We are some of the weakest creatures on our planet. Other species are bigger, stronger, tougher. They can fly high, swim deep, run fast, leap and bound. They have fur and feathers and thicker skin. We pride ourselves on opposable thumbs, theory of mind, vast intelligence. But because we cannot speak the language of other creatures we don't actually know how smart they are. (Maybe whales and porpoises, with their big brains, have happy lives with their families, are not burdened with material items.) We understand so little! And what we can imagine or theorize is all based on this itty bitty sliver of time and dirt we inhabit, based on the subsection of the species that studies such things, who admits that much of what is theorized doesn't even conform to natural laws as we experience them.
Look, I don't know shit about shit. Not physics or chemistry. My mind can't wrap around a million years, or even a light year. I don't want to live through a global pandemic or a zombie apocalypse. (Seriously, fuck zombies.) I just think that we have to throw all of our expectations out the window when imagining other life in the universe. Question every single expectation. Without open minds we will never get anywhere. But regardless, no one gets out alive. Death is a trip we will all take. We can only hope, whatever it is we hope. (Sorry this is super long, dis-jointed, and rambly. This only reflects my opinion based on my current knowledge. I am always trying to learn more. If you want to teach me something, or correct me where I'm wrong, you don't have to insult me to do it. I like civil discussions with people smarter than myself. I'm going to post it anyway.)

Let’s put it this way, every galaxy in existence has only one singular planet with life, intelligent or not. That would explain why we haven’t seen life out there and it would be due to there only being a singular intelligent species per galaxy. Knowing how many galaxies there are, there could be 1,000,000 civilizations and only a few have actually managed to reach interstellar travel, and most are on our state, still stuck on a single planet. Those few to reach that state of advancement could be millions of light years away or the galaxies closest to us. So really, there is a great chance that there is life, but the two questions that really matter are
How far is that life from us?
And
Is that life intelligent enough for us to understand each other or completely primitive?

Many are missing a huge point of this theory: the great filter. Earth itself has gone through really catastrophic scenarios through its history, and mankind either wouldn't exist or was nearly wiped out several times. You see, Universe itself has billions of years, and our history as civilized and cooperative beings is barely 12000 years. Chances are there were lots of civilizations around us throughout these billion years, and they lived thousands of years and eventually got wiped out by a cataclysmic event, just like we can be at any moment, and just like dinosaurs got extinct. Then you would say we would eventually find ruins: yes, maybe, or maybe a meteor collapsed their entire planet, or maybe were hit by a sudden gamma ray burst, or exploded their own world by misuse of their technology, and so on. The thing we miss is that we just recently got the technology to observe space, and not even that efficiently. Thinking that these thousands of years we exist as intelligent beings are any meaningful compared to billions of years of the universe existence and its possible timeframes is silly. So: has ever existed complex lifeforms around the universe during its timeframe? Quite probably, but not guaranteed, since complex life as we know needs A LOT of circumstances and events that enables it. Are they alive in our current timeframe? Maybe, for a huge coincidence, otherwise, we missed them by millions of years just like other civilizations might miss us.

TL;DR: Universe has billions of years. There might have been millions of wiped civilizations before us, and millions after we are extinct. To think intelligent life was supposed to manifest around the universe at the exact same time frame is silly and far-fetched.

I never understood the sentence “even if they travelled at the speed of light, it would still take x million years to reach y”. General relativity states that time and space dilation means that for a photon traveling the speed of light, space is infinitesimally thin, and time doesn’t pass, i.e. no time elapses between the emission of the photon and the absorption of the photon (from the perspective of the photon). So that would mean that travel, due to time and space dilation, is subject to the traveling observer, while the statement above is subject to a earthly observer. But the relevant observer is the traveler, right? For him, the travel would be instantaneous (plus acceleration and deceleration).

Our current limitation is material reductionism. It's assumed that all life is material. Maybe it's not. Maybe material life is rare and non-material life is the norm. We know there are dimensions beyond 4D. In those dimensions, there are no time-space limitations. You can go from A to B instantly because A and B occupy the same point. There may already be other intelligent life right here on Earth that exists parallel, watching us, but we can't see it because we lack the faculties or we are too focused on technology.

The Fermi Paradox is entirely predicated upon a material universe with material life. Maybe that's not how it works. The great filter probably has more to do with that. A species remains materialistically focused until their star goes nova and snuffs them out.

The other possibility is that what spiritual wisdom traditions say is true. When the physical body dies our consciousness leaves and goes elsewhere. Maybe the human experience is temporary and we're not supposed to leave Earth. When humanity eventually goes extinct, consciousness just finds another planet to be on. We don't even know yet what consciousness is. Evolution looks only at organic material and genetics. So far we don't even know the nature of the presence that is asking these questions. I wish science would focus more on that than building primitive machines to go to ridiculously far places. Maybe if we had better mastery over consciousness, we wouldn't even need technology to explore the universe?

Our first radio broadcast was 24 Dec 1906. That first broadcast 111 years ago has only traveled 111 light years. Ignoring the signal degradation over such distances, nothing outside of an 111 light year radius sphere could know we're here. The galaxy is about 100,000 light years across. Only 0.2% of the galaxy could know we're here. As for our detection capabilities, our biggest issue is time/distance. We've had a ridiculously tiny window to observe things. We're approximately 26000 light years out from the center of the galaxy. If someone on the other side of the galaxy (equidistant from the center) sent a message directed straight at us, It would've had to have been sent 52,000 years ago for us to get it now. The distances and times we're looking at are simply too ridiculous. Think of it this way: For someone to have received our first radio broadcast and sent a message back that we received today, they'd be less than 56 light years away. Compared to the size of the galaxy and everything else, that's minuscule. It might be that there's tons of life out there, we're just not in the right place at the right time to see it.

One thing that bothers me when people theorize about possible extraterrestrial life. We assume it would be something we would recognize as life. It's possible life could develop on a planet that's completely hostile to us, say on a gas giant like Jupiter. Beings from a planet like that wouldn't be interested in us or our planet

This whole so-called "paradox", to me, just seems like a really arrogant line of thinking that uses a lot of "what-ifs" like facts. "If aliens really exist, OBVIOUSLY they would have come to earth by now, because we're the most important planet ever right?". Assuming sustaining an interstellar to galactic civilization is even possible, (and it might not be), space is really big, colonizing planets is really hard, and we have absolutely no idea how long it could take to develop that kind of technology or when alien life first appeared on a given planet. Even then, I see no reason why a galactic empire would want to take over EVERY planet in the galaxy. It might just not be technologically practical or even possible, when you consider that (in addition to many planets being resource-poor or downright uninhabitable) most colonizations would be a one way trip and just communication between planets could take years, so unless faster-then-light is possible (which is likely impossible) there wouldn't be much point in building an empire that you can't even control.
So TL;DR, I would propose a "great barrier" type solution to the paradox, only instead of all civilizations wiping themselves out at a certain point, it's just really that hard to make an empire that big. (no one has developed the technology yet, and a type III civilization might not be possible) And if an alien civilization does exist, it just hasn't reached us yet, and might not care enough to actually do so, because we are not the centre of the universe.

There is no end to technological advances, unless we remain in our current society and run out of motivation. If all the brainpower, resources, and money that went into cell phones were instead focused on space travel, we would probably be on Mars already setting up a colony. A big weakness we have is how most aren't willing to do any research unless they can get something out of it. Most medical studies were funded by big corporations with an interest in the results. An interest that could pay back their investment many times over. This system sort of works, but it will not get us off this planet. A hundred years from now, we will probably still be spending a lot of brainpower and resources on technology that lets us work less, make more money, and increase our comfort. Few are looking at the big picture. If we don't escape this rock, we WILL go extinct. If we can escape this rock, we have a better chance at surviving as a species. If we can colonize the galaxy, our survive is almost assured. If we can colonize other galaxies, we will never go extinct.
