In regards to being unable to communicate with highly advanced life, I think this is a fallacy. In fiction there are often aliens so advanced that they can't communicate with us because we are like ants to them. However, WE can communicate with ants using synthetic pheromone trails. We can communicate with most animals, but only up to their level. You can teach a dog to do certain tasks and indicate to them what you want done, but you can't explain math or socioeconomics to them. It is reasonable to assume that a hyper advanced species would be able to communicate with us on our level. There would just be entire worlds of ideas that they would be unable to make us understand.

There seems to be this longstanding and unshakable belief that if aliens existed they’d be far more advanced and will have figured out physics we cannot begin to fathom and will use it to cut across space in a matter of hours to visit other worlds. It never seems to enter anyone’s minds that maybe there is no shortcut to travel and perhaps other worlds are no more advanced than the human race is. Or that aliens may have visited earth millions of years ago when it was a snow ball and decided that life did not and could not exist here and moved on. Or maybe they haven’t been any further than their own moons or haven’t even left the planet or have desire to do so. Why is it we assume that life does not exist because it’s not advanced enough to make contact in some way? What if, and I’m just snowballing here, humans are the most advanced beings in the galaxy?

Or maybe, just maybe, nothing truly can travel faster than light speed or there is no possible way to fold space and create wormholes to go from point A to point B without being destroyed. The idea that perhaps the only way to even possibly do so seems to be by a black hole but from what we know of those, black holes are well known for not letting anything that goes into remain in one piece. Physics have not made any real strides since the 30s despite all the advances in tech we’ve made, but they’re just evolutions of established science that’s not itself evolved in several decades. Not even string theory can be proved or disproved because in order to experiment or solve it would require access to dimensions impossible for us. In the end, we will probably never know one way or the next if life outside of our planet exists simply because there is just no way to find out

An idea of the great filter might be the following:

Getting over all the technological barriers, in order to start conquering other planets, a civilization needs to solve it's internal conflicts and be united under a single, centralized leadership. And we can imagine, seeing our history and it's tendency to repeat itself, that this is an incredibly hard to achieve feat. Most probably, the majority of the intelligent civilizations will never get beyond this step.

But let's assume that some species do pass this filter. What next? The nearest star may not host planets. Or even if it does, it may not have any planet in the habitable zone. Or even if it has such a planet, that planet may well be populated by another intelligent civilization, developed enough to defend itself against a colonizing ship. And if we take into consideration the possible diseases on the new planet, diseases that our conquering civilization has no immunity against or research about, then we can imagine how hard it would be to conquer the first planet.

Furthermore, let's assume that this conquering civilization gets to a first planet...then another one...and so on. It will get to the point of controlling about 8-10 planets. Keeping in mind that not every star would host a convenient planet, we can assume that the stars of the conquered planets won't be "close" neighbors. This means that even with wormhole technology, communication would go really slow. Moreover, as different planets have different environments, over the course of hundreds or thousands of years, the colonies would most probably suffer significant DNA changes that could even affect them psychologically. These 2 problems would make it nearly impossible for the civilization to keep itself united and internal conflicts would most likely emerge again, and we go back to the firs step mentioned. But this time, as the conflicts would be spread across various solar systems, not only across a planet's surface, it will take much, much, longer(if that ever happens) for the conflicts to be solved again.

The Drake Equation needs a many more additions:
Size of Star – a large star burns out quickly,
a small star has to have its planets very close and this causes many different problems in order for it to be in the location where it is warm enough to have liquid
- It would be tidally locked
- It would be so close to the star that solar flares would regularly bath the planet with radiation
- There would be a much small bandwidth of light for photosynthesis
Mass of planet – More Mass = more atmosphere = warmer planet (and the inverse is also true)

I don't see humanity technologically growing past the 21st century, or at least not very fast, simply because we are a group of divided nation states constantly at each others necks politically and ideologically. The way I see it, our species really stands no chance of expansion or development past this point unless the entire world is unified under one "Empire" (or republic or whatever the fuck you'd like to call it). Only then do we stand any chance of surviving the expanse.

But the issue that we still have is that there is no realistic chance of any kind of planetary unification happening unless there is something to unify against. I've noticed that people only come together in history when their is a great threat posse towards them. I mean take factions such as NATO or CSTO. A common group of nation states banding together in order to protect each other from other hostile nation states or factions (ironically).

We should also think about the issue of interstellar travel, in particular the ability to go FTL (Faster Then Light). There are many theoretical ways to go FTL, primarily Worm Holes and Warping. However unless some exotic matter that we have not discovered yet exists that allows us to bend gravity and make it our bitch, we have no realistic chance of reaching FTL. Also for those who don't know, the closer you get to the speed of light, the more mass you gain, so if you eventually hit the speed of light you would implode into a black hole of infinite mass. This is such a popular question, and yet the answer is so simple and overlooked. If extraterrestrials exist, why haven't they revealed themselves to us? Just look around you and you'll see the answer, many of us are already accusing them of being evil and they haven't even said hello yet. Think about this for a second, outside of our internet and media, there is literally no information regarding aliens and their intentions. What we "know" is taken from movies or obscure websites like Reddit and 4chan where anyone can say anything. But, for some reason a very large portion of us think we have it all figured out. The arrogance is deafening. Sometimes, we'll see a report of a UFO on the news, but there's no real information there. Aliens have not revealed themselves because, we as the human species are not easily swayed by facts or evidence, we are a heavily opinionated and hard-headed species, we will hold onto our histories. Even as old information gathered throughout our history is discovered to be flawed through new science and technology, we've still built our societies and cultures around those flaws, and will not look to new ideas or innovations so easily. You can see this even now. Things such as life-extension for humans by hundreds or even thousands of years is seen as controversial, some people say they wouldn't want to live that long, they don't see a point in living thousands of years. The reasons they give for not wanting to live that long are hardly even thought out. They'll get bored is one of the most popular reasons put forth - and that is foolish. With so many innovations and ideas in reach such as quantum computing, avoiding death, traveling and inhabiting different planets, possibly interacting with other alien civilizations and exploring their various cultures and arts, I really have to question how in this universe anyone can say they would get bored. A person incapable of deep, critical thinking would say they would get bored, and it's those types of people (and they are abundant) that I think are problematic to an alien race trying to reveal themselves to a group who are already half-ignorant to their existence. They can probably hide whatever traces of their existence they want from us and will continue to do so until we evolve a bit more in our heads. We may only ever know what they want us to know.

I have a theory. If we assume life on other planets began existing around the same time it did on earth, and followed a similar rate of advancement, then the most civilizations wouldn't be observable by us anyway. Because when we observe planets and stars many light years away, we're looking back in time. Therefore, we would only be able to observe planets that are, at least in theory, only just starting to develop more complex life. This life could take completely different evolutionary paths, but because of the time discrepancy of observing planets so far away, there's simply no way for us, at the present, to see life on other earth-like planets. However, if the technology to observe planets directly ever became possible, theoretically we would be able to witness the beginning of life, since the time discrepancy would allow us to observe their evolution

Well according to the dark forest theory, the two axioms are that first, a civilization's survival is its primary need, and second, civilizations continuously develop and expand, yet the amount of matter remains the same within the universe. That being said, due to so many unknown factors about other civilizations, once one discovers another, it immediately becomes threatened - unless they are so technologically advanced that they can learn all about that civilization, down to the atoms and how each one of the biological components of an individual functions in sufficient time (so there is nothing for them to hide in any sort of conversation), during which the species may have become extinct, moved away, evolved, whatever. Therefore, the safest option would be to use a weapon difficult to detect and difficult, if not impossible to stop on that civilization, to ensure that it never becomes a threat, or will no longer be a threat. This mostly eliminates the possibility of some sort of other alien civilization that knows about our existence and has not taken action - of course, unless they are unaware of this theory, or, perhaps, reasons we fail to comprehend, I suppose.

They missed one other possible answer to the Fermi Paradox:  Any intelligent life is purposefully keeping silent, not communicating and not exploring:  Why?  Because they have no idea what they will find, and it is very likely it will be hostile.  Silence is a safety measure, and frankly, although that is terrifying, it makes perfect sense.  People assume first contact will be with something benevolent, but the opposite is very likely, and would probably kill us.  The aliens are using that same logic.

I can't help but feel a bit annoyed by these 2 videos. If you do a bit of research you'll find plenty of good info on the subject. Retired personnel from the Airforce and other military backgrounds with high level security clearance have given first hand accounts about experiences they've witnessed but were ordered at the time to keep quiet or risk losing their career.
The subject has been suppressed for at least 70 years (the Roswell incident was in July 1947) and people have been conditioned through the media to not take anything UFO related seriously, just laugh it off, dismiss it, and make jokes about it, ridicule it and call anyone who says they saw a UFO "weird".

The most cringe thing is seeing people like these type of thoughts and put it on a high pedestal. Really, to me, this is all just normal thought and is good to encourage but not obsess over. Just put philosophical and scientific things in the same boat as cleaning the toilet bowl.

What we see on our own planet makes it unlikely that no other life exists in our universe. As we progress in our understanding of how our universe works and if we are smart enough to not destroy ourselves we will reach other planets, possibly other galaxies, perhaps other universes. We will evolve as evolution is driven by the strange need to survive. If we survive long enough we will inevitably find life of varying degrees of intelligence. To think that in the end of our universe all this evolution will prove useless does not make sense unless we die failing to evolve far enough. There is a reason for existence. The reasons may involve intelligent design but this begets the question from whence did the designer come. To think that sentience from our universe will cease to exist at what is thought to be the death of our universe does not make sense unless we in our universe have not evolved far enough. Evolution is the compelling proof that there is a reason for existence. One day hopefully descendants of our species will understand.

We actually do know that we haven't hit the limit for technological progress yet. It is because of this that researchers around the world are looking into quantum computers as well as optical ones (Optic Computing is basicly computers that operate at the speed of light.. Basicly meaning you wont have to worry about too few fps ever again). What we do know is that we might be near the end of Moores law (Moore's law is the observation that the number of transistors in a dense integrated circuit/processor doubles approximately every two years). To reach the end of Moores Law, means that we must reach the physical limit for how small the number of transistors in an effective dense integrated circuit can be. Some say that we are close to the end of that, however there is a team of researchers somewhere who are trying to make atoms themselves into transistors, which means that we will be able to get some serious processors going on in the future (transistors are like a light switch. When the light is on it equals 1. When the light is off, it equals 0. A computer works in 1s and 0s. 0000=0, 1111=15, 1010=10 and 0101=5. 1111=15 because 1111 is 8421 in bits)

I've always hated that "try communicating with an animal" analogy for aliens. It's shit. Squirrels can't communicate ideas at all. They don't have the self-awareness to know what an idea is, nor do they have the desire to communicate it with us. So of course we can't communicate ideas with them. Humans can use logic, they are self-aware, they can communicate ideas, they know what they are. They have language, and the ability to record their ideas and build off of them. They have the desire to communicate.

Comparing that to something that inherently can't communicate on any real level, and has no desire to, is a shitty analogy. Another species with logic, the desire to communicate, advanced language, etc. should be able to find a way to communicate, even if it's difficult at first.

Just because aliens may have more complex ideas or ways of thinking than we do, doesn't mean that we're squirrels to them. If anything, their intelligence should make it easier to communicate, because they'll be able to come up with an intelligent system and think of many possibilities to make it work. And thinking that they won't check radio waves signals for signs of life? That would mean they aren't very smart at all. If their goal was to find life, and they were super-intelligent, they're going to be including many forms of possible communication... and something as fundamental as using wavelengths of light? Uh yeah, that would be included.

Another, more terrifying solution is the Dark Forest theory. The base assumptions are that 1. civilizations generally seek self-preservation, 2. in order to survive, civilizations must grow, and 3. technological progress is nonlinear and unpredictable. To show how this works, we're going to use Civilization A and Civilization B. A is more technologically advanced than B at the start of our thought experiment, but the 3rd axiom/assumption means that B could be more advanced than A in a matter of years. A discovers B, around 10 or so LY from A's host star but B doesn't know about A. A knows it can't keep its existence a secret from B for too long and that its technological lead is unsubstantial and likely to change eventually, both due to the 3rd axiom. Additionally, there's no way for A to know for sure whether or not B is benevolent or malevolent so, logically, the only course of action for A to take is the complete annihilation of civilization B. The logical extension of this is that there may be millions of civilizations in our galaxy, but each of them reached the dark forest conclusion independently and they know broadcasting any signals for long enough is suicide. We could be one among millions or billions of intelligent species in a perpetual standoff, each forced to murder anyone who speaks up

Why We Should Really Stop Trying to Contact Aliens ...

"...Cixin’s dark forest metaphor goes like this:

The universe is a dark forest. Every civilization is an armed hunter stalking through the trees like a ghost, gently pushing aside branches that block the path and trying to tread without sound. Even breathing is done with care. The hunter has to be careful, because everywhere in the forest are stealthy hunters like him. If he finds another life — another hunter, angel, or a demon, a delicate infant to tottering old man, a fairy or demigod — there’s only one thing he can do: open fire and eliminate them.

And here’s us with our desire for contact:

But in this dark forest, there’s a stupid child called humanity, who has built a bonfire and is standing before it shouting, “Here I am! Here I am!...”"

The way I see it  , if theres life out there, its playing smart and shutting the fuck up, and so should we. If we discover aliens and they discover us, we would have to decide "Is it safe having super intelligent species that could shoot a rock at out our planet at relativistic speed and end us. ". And they would be thinking precisely the same thing. Even if theres only a 10% chance of the other guy being a bad guy, is it worth risking extinction on that bet? So  the smart thing is to stay as silent as possible, and if you catch another civilization making noise, nuke them, before they get a chance to nuke you. In a dark forest of predators, survival is a zero sum game.

I'm 40 years and I've always been into science. I've watched the night sky for years looking at stars and stuff. 2 weeks ago this question was answered for me. Are we alone in the universe? No we are not and I am 100% certain there is something here watching us. What it's agenda and purpose is I have no idea. I'm not a simple minded person and what I saw there is no earthly explanation for. I live 2 blocks north of Detroit. I went out on the porch to have a cigarette. 2 cop cars went racing down the street at a high rate of speed. I thought to myself they're after someone. So I walked out to the side walk to see what was going on. The cop cars pulled into a parking lot and turned off their lights. Then I looked up to the sky. There were six bright lights high in the sky. I couldn't see them from my porch because of the trees. The lights were over a mile away. They were very bright unlike aircraft and they were clustered together. They seemed to merge with each other and break apart. Then they disappeared one at a time and reappeared in another part of the sky almost instantly. I've used telescopes and I've seen a lot of different aircraft everything from AC130's warthogs f16's passanger jets large and small black hawk helicopters. I've seen many things in the sky but I've come to the conclusions this wasn't earthly. We are not alone. I've seen video of the exact same phenomenon in other states and other countries from around the world. We are being visited. One day mankind is going to find out. I just hope what ever it is it's not hostile.

I've been trying to figure out the fastest way to get to mars and from my estimates it would take ~2 weeks with ion propulsion (theoretical, not real yet).
If we were to use normal space shuttle fuel (liquid hydrogen and oxygen) to exit the atmosphere it would use about 2.5 million lbs of fuel. When outside the atmosphere we use about 1/3 of the fuel to get to the moon (2/3 of it is the part used to exit the atmosphere). So we COULD theoretically use normal rocket fuel to get OUT of the atmosphere but then use something like Ion propulsion (which is a form of electric propulsion that creates thrust by accelerating ions with electricity). Ion propulsion DOES need quite a bit of electricity to get started so I propose that we (once we have the technology) use a fusion reactor to provide electricity to both the shuttle AND the ion thrusters
If anything doesn't make sense please tell me and I will fix it

i think the kardashev scale is naive. sure once you reach type 2 and harness a whole star it would be a dramatic leap. huge. but after a while every dyson complex around them would reach a point where it would need more than just another star and yet another star. instead you would need an exponential leap. because eventually your power needs would require more than just acquiring another star. kind of like regular computers vs quantum. eventually you can never add enough classical computing power. you need the exponential increase of quantum. so i think type 3 would be more than just harnessing star after star in a whole galaxy. you would reach a point where you would figure out greater forms of energy than just chaotic stars. interesting thought i guess.

One problem I've always had with the idea of warlike aliens (though predicated on human examples, so of course there's the possibility of aliens that just find war their reason for existence or something): War has 2 main motivators: economical scarcity and ideological conflict.

Scarcity on a galactic scale is all but inconceivable - There's so much stuff just sitting out there that there's really no reason to fight over it. (Again, this is thinking on a human example; there's the possibility of some super-resource hungry supertech out there that actually demands the kind of resources needed to make a galactic empire have to deal with scarcity)

Ideological conflict is all but inevitable between life forms, but I'd argue that, by and large, the observable trend is that more sophisticated intelligences tend to not resort to the "blow it all up" button. Compare the Cold War to the Crusades, for instance.

In the Crusades, a bunch of Europeans said to the Muslim world "your religion is wrong" and as a result decided to walk over to the Muslim part of the world and start killing people (until the Muslims demonstrated that they were better at killing people, at which point the Europeans kinda called it all off and started practicing on eachother again).

In the Cold War, a much more technologically sophisticated United States told a similarly sophisticated Soviet Union (and vice versa, I kinda get the impression that it wasn't either side exclusively that started the Cold War) and said "Communism is wrong." The Soviets said "Communism is right! See, we have people orbiting the planet! And nukes! Lots of nukes!" To which the US said "We have lots of nukes too! Oh, and that guy walking on the moon is American!" And so on. Point is, unlike the primitives in medieval Europe, nobody pressed decided that the solution to the disagreement was to make everyone die...just to make sure that they all died if one of them decided to kill all us. Small progress, granted, but...progress!

Granted, there are also still religious people around who decide to kill all the dissenting religious people they can find, but this is a minority. No country ...at least as far as I've heard... openly supports the religious groups that go about doing that. And the general consensus of the international community is that you really shouldn't be doing that even if you're keeping it quiet. A dramatic difference from medieval Europe, no?

My point is, if you scale up maturity along with technology, by the time you hit technology capable of sustaining an interstellar empire...or even just practical interstellar travel at all...you've probably got a species that's long since figured out that war isn't a productive method of solving problems.

What's far more terrifying to me is the indifferent aliens. Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy provides a good example (despite the absurd reasoning) - aliens just drop by, say "Earth needs to not be here" and wipe us out along with our planet. At that point, it's not really war, any more than stepping on an ant is. There's no risk of resources, we're just the ant that got underfoot, or that squirrel failing to comprehend why the forest needed to be cut down. If we're lucky, our first contact scenario (assuming that's aliens dropping in to visit, not us going out there) is with a Star Trek Federation type, or maybe the Centauri from Babylon 5 (exploitive trade deals are survivable when compared to some alternatives.) If not, our biggest problem is likely going to be getting them to comprehend that we're sapient and shouldn't be squished.

If we're really lucky, those jokes about how humans and a lot of the animals we just deal with on a regular basis are actually kinda terrifying. :p

I think the most likely solution to the Fermi Paradox is this. I think the aliens are out there and they are quite common. They have a culture, or at least a moral code, somewhat like ours, "Don't hurt one another" so they have prohibitions against killing, stealing, or beating each other up. But unlike what most of science fictions tells us, they don't look anything like us, or each other. They all evolved independently on different planets with different environments.
They look at as and they see a single species, all looking more or less the same, with some slight differences in how dark brown they are. They see how we treat each other, based on how brown we are, and this deeply disturbs them. If we treat each other like we do based on skin color, how would we treat them, when they are so utterly alien?
They are out there, possible many species having cultural exchanges and trading goods, while we sit here fouling our own environment and killing each other because we worship the wrong false God, or because we were born on the wrong side of some imaginary line, or because our skin is too dark or too light.
They don't look at us and see an intelligent species. They see monsters. Worse, when we depict aliens in our stories we have them telling us how much potential we have.

As I understand space and time... If we we're to travel in light speed to a distant starsystem or something similar the perception of time would be entirely different depending on where you we're observing the travel.

Hypothetically, if a spaceship was to instantly accelerate to light speed (99.99999999%) to a star system 1000 light years away. The people on the spaceship would observe them arriving instantly. However, people observing this from earth would perceive the trip to take 1000 years.

If you reading this, was to hitch a ride with a light photon. (Hypothetical speaking) that was traveling from the sun to earth. Everyone on earth would perceive the travel time to take about 8 minutes and 20 seconds. You, however, would perceive the travel time as an instant. You would instantly arrive at earth due to time dilation.

Okay, so let's travel to a star system 10 light years away. Let's say we have an incredibly advanced spaceship and we can travel in 85% of lightspeed. We put one clock in the spaceship and one on earth.

When the spaceship takes off and begins it's travel the time on the spaceship will move slower. The clock will tick slower in relation to the clock on earth. However it is not observable for the people in the spaceship at the time. They will perceive time as moving at the same rate as on earth.

When you arrive at your destination, let's say you can compare the two clocks again. What you would see is that the trip that took 10 years for observers at earth, only took about 5 years for the spaceship.

This is disregarding the fact that light needs to travel back to earth for them to observe it.


How much time slows down by is exponential, that means the closer you come to the speed of light the more drastically time slows down by. This is why at 99.999999999% you would arrive there instantly. However 85% only slows time down and dilates the distance to a very rough estimate of about 50%.

It is not just the time that dilates either, it is the distance too.

May I just remind everyone that we have very VERY primitive tools for investigating the universe? Sure, by 1900 standards we are at sci-fi levels, but for example when scientists investigate planets in other star systems, they look at black spots periodically passing in front of their stars (planets). That is hardly sufficient to call 'we've seen it all, there is nothing out there'.

How arrogant can we be to assume that somehow this magical planet of ours is unique? You heard the numbers, if it happened once, it absolutely MUST HAVE happened more than once, unless there is something absolutely unique about our planet (and if you think there is, I would like to hear what it is).

The reason we haven't detected life and especially sentient life is because our tools are simply not up to scratch. A unified planetary government elevating and industrialising our planet to current western standards, dumping the cost of warfare altogether would free up ENORMOUS resources that could be dedicated to spacey stuff, so we are nowhere near to our limits!

Maybe it all comes down to weather or not we can unify our race before we destroy each other.

My theory: There might be life forms out there but not intelligent. Intelligence is extremely costly on the scale of evolutionary advantages. For once, a big and complex brain needs a lot of energy and is hard to sustain. Second, an intelligent brain needs time to grow after birth just to function, our babies are completely helpless during more than a year after birth. Compared to almost every  other mammal, whose offspring are capable of running, using their senses to identify objects, avoid obstacles and have basic survival instincts hours after birth, our babies are pathetic. Intelligent is an evolutionary advantage, but only after the development of tools and basic understanding. However for tools to develop, an intelligent species needs to survive with all those setbacks for generations before it gains any advantages. So maybe intelligent life is extremely rare, and we are the sole winners of the intelligence lottery in the galaxy against incredible odds.

Here is a thought, maybe we should ask who are we looking for? I think the answer is us. SETI is searching for a human like civilisation probably within 200 to 300 years in advance of our own. Is there any reason to be surprised we haven't found one? Any sufficiently advanced technology will most likely be indistinguishable from nature. Technology almost always moves toward greater complexity and greater efficiency, less energy to do more work, so no Dyson spheres. Eventually a advanced civilisation will simply stop wasting energy broadcasting radio noise into space. Think the planet Pandora from the movie Avatar. Even the scientists thought they were on a primitive planet inhabited by a stone age people. A planet where the animals and people have built in USB ports. Where the plant life forms a planet wide fibre optic neural network that the locals can upload themselves to when they're near death. A planet with at least one mineral that can't possibly be a product of nature. We would no more recognise a super advanced civilisation than a mouse would recognise an iPhone as anything other that a shiny rock. The Fermi Paradox is most likely not a valid concept, it makes to many assumptions based on a linear view of our own technology. A technology that does not follow a linear path and never has.

But couldn't the Fermi paradox just be answered with this:

The Universe is virtually infinite. It has infinite places with infinite different outcomes of existence. In this infinite Universe, there is bound to be places with intelligent life. Among this life there is bound to be sophisticated cultures capable of space travel. Hence there are also areas where this life can travel. However, there also must be places where this life cannot reach.

Maybe we just happen to exist in one of those dark, quiet corners of the Universe.

Do you think this is a valid answer? Why not? I would love to know.

Experts believe that within 30 years we will achieve eternal youth. Also let's imagine that we we are all a computer simulation. What would our purpose be? Let's say, hypothetically, that the species that created us evolved into a universe full of aliens and galactic empires. Since the universe has been conquered, there is no more advancement, as other species had already advanced to that point. As the newest and stupidest species, they are treated like dirt, and can't get good jobs. Eventually their planet is destroyed or taken through eminent domain. Because all the other planets were taken by other species, they are forced to spread out, hitchhiking from planet to planet begging for food. Or maybe the empire had slavery, they just abolished it, and rights for other species aren't exactly the best. Either way, they evolved way to late, and suffer for it. Now let's say one of them has a question, what would happen if back when we evolved we were the only intelligent life in the universe? Now let's say we are that simulation, Fermi paradox solved. We can't find any aliens because there are none, and there are none because the person who created the simulation wanted there not to be.

Here's some reasoning as to why we've encountered no-one yet:
1) The universe is vast in both space and time. It's not even vaguely realistic to expect to contact something half way across the milky way at around 50,000 light years let alone from another galaxy.
Is a conversation that takes 1,000 years from question to reply realistic? Then how about 100,000 years?
2) Civilizations (I think) will mostly burn brightly, use all their resources and die back in a few measly centuries. (We're certainly tearing through our resources and our population's growing exponentially-[it's been pointed out to me it's not exponential, so let's say very fast?]). So the odds of industrialized intelligence being 'there' when we or they look are hugely remote.
Life on Earth took 3,500,000 years to get from the single celled to us having radio, that's 3 1/2 Billion years to our having inter-planetary communication ability. (We've been able to send / receive radio, etc. for 120 years out of 3 1/2 Billion.) The communication analogy is a little silly. As far as physics is concerned we have basically discovered the four fundamental forces neccessary for everything. One of those, E&M, lends itself to communication. This is because of the relativistic speed limit. The only conceivable way to transmit information faster would be too use some sort of worm hole through which you would still send E&M communication because it is easier and more reliable than anything else. So where are the E&M messages? They don't exist because there is no intelligent life within our galaxy that is still alive (ignoring weird hibernating type cases mentioned in the video)

“I’m sure the universe is full of intelligent life. It’s just been too intelligent to come here.” -Arthur C. Clarke

I had an existential crisis while watching this spectacular video. I know full well that I probably will not live to see the majority of human history - provided we don't destroy ourselves in the next 50 years - or even our first contact with alien life. Though, on the topic of aliens, two reasons we may not have seen life before could be:
1) For the most part the technology that we use is based around specular light, and the observation of fluctuation and interference from the many types of Waves and Rays on the electromagnetic spectrum. I mean we can't even observe all forms of energy on the electromagnetic spectrum. In all likelihood Alien life that is able to traverse the Galaxy would probably have some way of warping or bend light to make it so that we are not able to observe them or there effect on space.
2) Why would life that is able to explore the vastness of space come to see us? MAYBE, if they hadn't seen any other form of "intelligent" life besides themselves before they might come to us in hopes of communication. Or just MAYBE they would like to experiment on us for the sake of science but besides that I can't imagine a space faring species ever wasting the resources necessary for such insignificant purposes. Many of the other habitable planets in the galaxy - by our definition - are a lot larger than our own planet and have an abundance in resources and if they did have life, would probably be far more interesting based on the pure quantity of life.
Then there is the idea that alien may come here to harness our resources. Why? Sure if they used an automated system as described by the video, we might just end up being a target but, considering planets such a Venus and Mercury and even the gas giants have such a vast amount of potential for energy production, I doubt the earth would be a target even in our own solar system. Jupiter, although dangerous to traverse, has over a few hundred times our own mass and more potential energy than all the other planets combined and why wouldn't they want that, or even our Sun? See, this is why I love Kurgesagt, they gives us so much to think about and many ideas and concepts to form in our minds. And of course in saying that, I pose to interesting questions. What do you, people of the internet, think of the "Fermi Paradox" and why do you think we haven't yet been able to make contact with other Alien species?

I personally feel like the overwhelming physical problems with travel prohibit life from expanding beyond their own star system.

There is no way we know of to possibly go faster than light. You can't even get close without requiring prohibitively (talking mass of stars here) large amounts of energy.
Besides that there is the destructive influence of cosmic radiation frying every living thing it touches. Imagine if you will a species that can get fast but not relativistically fast travel and put together a generation ship to another star system. But before they got there they had to have generations bombarded by cosmic radiation which caused so many genetic abnormalities and cancer that there was no conceivable way they could fight it all. Maybe they did discover a way to get to the other star, but on the way they were destroyed by the reality that life just cannot withstand high level atomic particles ripping apart our dna.

The Matrioshka Brain concept is a very interesting one. If the universe is strictly governed by a speed limit, and there is no feasible way to cross vast expanses of the empty universe except through many, many, many, many many years of travel.... it might be that retreating to a virtual world, idealized to your personal tastes, becomes the favored life choice for a sizable chunk of humanity. I imagine after a certain age, when you've already gone through those intense feelings of childhood and early adulthood, and you have no leanings towards certain occupations like teaching, higher sciences, arts, space exploration, etc.... then you might have no qualms about uploading your "consciousness", or putting a virtual copy of one into a simulation along with some of your closest friends and family, and spending as long as you like in there.

Of course, there is the question of what consciousness is, or what the true nature of it is. Do you close your eyes and then open them into a virtual world? Or do you die, and a copy of you, that really isn't "you" per se, live on in the simulation?

its unlikely that a visiting species would be hostile.  simply put, its far easier to harvest multiple planets wirth of resources in a lower gravity environment such as asteroid belts and oort clouds.  unless they are borg like assimilators that desire our knowledge and experience via force, its far easier to mine lifeless systems rather than drop into gravity wells for the same stuff that can be harvested cheaply in space.  not to mention risk.  microbes on earth (war of the worlds) could make our common cold thier version of Motaba.  in terms of efficiency and risk vs reward, theres no reason to even visit earth unless it is for cultural or trade reasons.  you dont get powerful enough to cross a galaxy by bieng inefficient.  it is also possible that certain techs, like say teleportation, ftl, or gravity manipulation are actually quite easy.  we just havent stumbled upon them yet.  an advanced spacefaring species may have all of this, but have yet to build a supercollider.  we may also be doing things the wrong way because our notions of physics are flawed.  einstien once said that no amount of testing could prove him right, but one experiment could prove him wrong.  just because everything we know to be true checks out now, does not neccisarily mean it will always be so.  i laud rogue ideas, even if wrong.  they force us to approach things differently and even if wrong, could spark an experiment that finds something new.

Y'know, it's actually highly probable that we already DO exist in a simulated universe inside another simulated universe inside another simulated universe etc. An effective simulation wouldn't be limitless ecstasy; rather it would probably be pretty similar to...well, how our world is now.

second comment in a short period i know.. but listen, if you were traveling at or near the speed of light across the milky way galaxy, the time you would experience to do so would be highly altered. If you were traveling at the speed of light, literally no time would pass for you. The amount of time experienced increases by how slow you are compared to light. For instance astronauts on the ISS experience time at a slightly slower rate than on earth. After an average stay on the ISS an astronaut is several seconds younger than they were had they stayed on earth for an "equal" period of time.

I'm skeptical mankind will become extinct before earth becomes inhospitable (earth become uninhabitable in about 1 billion years due to the suns luminosity increasing by about 1% every 100 million years). We have already reached and almost passed the first test of advanced civilization, the power of splitting an atom. Granted no one has used it owing to fear, but in time fear becomes complacency and thus leads to no nuclear holocaust. The second test of civilization is unification. As I see the world today, steps are being taken to unite the world. The internet unites the world's thoughts, English is quickly becoming the most used language (both second and primary) used in the world. So, the world is quickly on it's way to unification. The last test is the  one I'm concerned about. What happens when humans discover the power of anti-matter, dark energy, and dark matter? Your guess is as good as mine. I suspect we have about 100-200 years before we have a grand unified theory of everything. Once (if) we have that, I believe that humans will have their gateway to the stars and will be a a type I civilization that controls the entire energy of our home planet. Once humanity is united, there is little that is impossible to us. In fact, using the technology we have today, we could colonize our entire galaxy in about 50 million years, a blink of an eye in the lifetime of the universe.

Firstly. You assume FTL travel is even possible. Perhaps it is impossible for any civilization, Just assume for a moment that no matter how advanced the civilization they cannot break the light speed barrier & travel to distant worlds in a timely manner. Consider our fastest ship voyager1 would take approximately 75 thousand years to reach even our closest stellar neighbor proxima centauri(4.25LY). Given the nature of life, life dies. Artificial life is a possibility to survive the longest journeys but even mechanical needs maintenance & replacement parts for malfunctions to keep going & there isn't a local auto parts store in space.

Secondly any species who wanted to visit earth would only do so for the resources of life. Gold, water, any other element on the periodic table can be found in abundance throughout the universe. The only need to come to a habitable planet for resources is if that resource is the inhabitants. Which means either A, humans are food or B humans are slaves. Self replicating robots would have little use for slaves & probably have other energy sources than protein. Which means biological & again biological would not survive the journey.

I do not see any species so malevolent to just sterilize the galaxy just for kicks. no motivation.

Oh also, you cannot "upload" yourself to any computer. At best, you can upload a duplicate. If you uploaded yourself & was instantly killed in the process the you would still be dead. Only a copy would remain but the original would be gone.

0.09 Mew

Some other ideas:

1. Self destruction. The Internet didn't really happen on an everyday-person level until around 1990. We've been in the global Internet age for a whopping 25 years. Our species is INSANELY YOUNG. Only in its infancy. As technology progresses, it will become easier and easier for us to destroy ourselves. 3D printing, bio-engineering, nano-technology, etc., all could potentially open doors to doomsday scenarios. Perhaps most intelligent life throughout the galaxy has just destroyed itself.

Tangent: Humans are still warring and murdering each other like savages, allowing destructive regimes like North Korea to progress, denying the most basic rights to billions (e.g. Chinese Internet censorship, free-thought/religious/women's rights in Middle East, oligarchies in Africa). To make it through our next filters, at the very least, we'll need to stop thinking of ourselves on generational timescales and start thinking of the bigger picture. How will humans in 1000 or more years look back on us? The word "savages" really is a relative term. Stop thinking with a 2016 mentality.

2. The singularity. If it happens, however it plays out, it could completely wipe out our entire sense of anything and everything. If suddenly computers start solving problems and making decisions, our goals and aspirations (or those of advanced alien civilizations) may completely change. If AIs engineer themselves to be trillions of times (infinitely?) smarter than 2016 humans, will they still value space travel? Who knows what they will value.

3. Fortune. Modern humans evolved during the ice age, which means that evolution happened very quickly due to small population sizes and aggressive natural selection. If our planet didn't have ice ages, it's probable that the first creature to evolve enough to take control of the earth would be much dumber than us, more destructive, more warring, more aggressive, less environmentally-conscious. If this is the case, it would suggest that the ice age made us smart enough to not destroy ourselves and to pass through more filters. Most other planets with the right conditions for life would not experience such specific conditions as to force a species to evolve intelligence past a self-destructible state. Thus, survivable intelligent life is much more rare than it otherwise seems.

4. Magic. Actually, probably the most popular viewpoint. The majority of earthlings and every culture in history believe in a magic god or something similar to explain things that they cannot otherwise explain.

5. Alien altruism. If they're out there, it actually seems fairly likely that they are watching us right now. With our primitive minds, it's hard for us to understand why they would just sit by and watch. Maybe they just have a much better sense of environmental stewardship than we do. They don't want to interfere for ethical reasons.

6. Physical limitations. There's a lot of information online about how humans ever visiting other stars in the flesh is actually fairly unlikely. In 2005, NASA unveiled its Space Launch System, which would take us to Mars. It was referred to as "Apollo on steroids." In other words, the same basic technology as the 1969 moon landing, but bigger. The Elon Musk-types are inspiring us by making space travel more affordable and interesting, but ultimately using the same modest force of propulsion.

My answer to the Fermi Paradox:

The Fermi Paradox has morphed into the Rare Earth Hypothesis: while
microbes (unicellular organisms with little internal structure) are
ubiquitous, requiring little more than planets in habitable zones,
multicellular life built from eukaryotic cells is very rare. Hence we
humans could well be unique in the Milky Way.

Keep in mind that nearly 4B years were required for multicellular animals to appear on earth. For animals to acquire science and technology required another 600M+ years. We humans have understood basic math and the scientific method for less than 500 years. Engines of any kind are only 250 years old. Electricity is barely 200 years old. That the universe consists of many galaxies, and radio transmission and reception, have been known for only about a century. The current understanding of evolution, mating DNA and natural selection, and electronic calculation and data processing, are only 60 years old. Our species is in its infancy.

My answer to the Fermi Pardox:

So life on each in some form has existed for 3.6 billion years, of which only 250K years was intelligent human (because let's face the dinosaurs and megafauna weren't going to develop space travel and advanced galactic communication), but modern human technology capable of significant communication and observation for only the last 100 years...that means that using our own planet as an example (certainly a ludicrously small sample size but the best we've got) only 100 'life years' out of 3.6 billion life years (100/3,600,000,000) has been anything that could MAYBE observe/be observed by other life forms. That means there's about a 1 in 36 million chance that a 'life year' of a planet is 'observable'

In the first part of this series the numbers posited were that if 0.1% of habitable planets developed life that's about 1 million planets with life. Even with 1 million possibilities each would still have to overcome the 1 in 36 million odds of being observable. Again, very rough, fuzzy math and not based on a meaningful sample (LOL, 1 planet), but still in that example the odds actually AREN'T great that one of the 1 million potential planets with life has OBSERVABLE life.

I think the squirrel analogy from the video is moderately flawed, as the human->squirrel interaction is typically altered in the event we are aware that our intervention will result in the extinction of a species.
A more analogous behavior involves the type 3 civilization finding some way to preserve a small sample of the population.
This is however, assuming that a) it knows the consequences of it's actions, which if they're this advanced they probably would to be fair, and b) the way they operate is similar to the way in which we operate, which is unknowable, but the entire squirrel analogy itself is based upon that idea to begin with.

If I had to guess, I'd say that intelligent life hasn't been seen either because life never survived that long, or because there's bigger goals out there for smarter life forms than to find other smart life forms. Like, when you're a kid and you play soccer/football, you always want to be the goalie/keeper because it's fun to use your hands. But then when you get older, you realize being the goalie/keeper is, like, the hardest, most stressful, most important job, and you don't go near it unless that's what you've been training for. From a human perspective, we aren't trained to find life on other planets, we're trained to not die, so I think we'll solve immortality before we solve interstellar travel. But humans who can live forever will have very different goals than humans that may not even make a century.

There's a book (Pushing Ice) where one ancient alien's solution to the Fermi Paradox was to bring advanced civilizations to them.  They built a Dyson Sphere and sent probes throughout the galaxy.  When a probe discovered a spacefaring civilization, the probe would capture the ship and head to the Sphere.  The probes would plot a course and speed such that all the different probes would reach the Sphere at the same point of time in the far future.  So Probe #1 might capture a human ship around Saturn 200 years in the future and Probe #2 captures a ship 10,000 light years away and a million years in the future, but both probes would arrive at the Sphere at roughly the same time.  And thanks to time dilation from near light speed travel, both ship crews would only experience a few months of time before arriving at the sphere.  Thus different civilizations separated by thousands of years and light-years can meet.

I think intelligent life is rarer than the drake equation suggest. On Earth out of a billion species we're the only intelligent ones and for most of our time on the planet having enough intelligence to reliably create fire was enough to ensure our survival. Evolution will work the same way on any planet with a self replicating system subjected to environmental selective pressure (ie life) on Earth survival of the fittest meant pretty much every species around us every single possible adaptation to the environment. Intelligence was not commonly selected for. Animals became faster stronger smaller able to fly ect ect. Only one species became intelligent enough to create technology. And this also requires not only high intelligence but also a social species. A race of super intelligent IQ 200 lions would never develop a nuclear bomb because you require a team of specialists all working together. Life span also has to be relatively high. Few species on this planet naturallly live more than a decade. Then there's the question is travel to other stars even possible. If we do ever build a generational ship it will take thousands of years to reach the closest star (any number of things can go wrong along the way) and even then what can you do with a few thousand people in a remote solar system? You would need to have access to water and oxygen at the very least for human biology.

May I suggest doing a video on the Rare Earth Hypothesis? It seems like the most sound reason for why we are alone in the universe. The huge amount of hurdles that Earth had to jump over to support life is astonishing. And it was all by chance!

Possible Solutions: Solution 1- intelligent life is fairly rare Solution 2- most intelligent life simply does not find exploring the universe and contacting other species interesting Solution 3- most intelligent life does not have the required manipulators to build sophisticated tools (look at dolphins for example). Each of these solution can be used on their own, or combined with others.

If I'd have seen this video ten years ago, I'd have laughed myself back to high school. But the fact that what was "science fiction" back then is practically a part of our daily lives now has shown me that once they get a foothold, humans are a bunch of tenacious little bastards. Right now, there's too many weak links in the chain for the entire human race to transcend. It's highly unlikely that the technology for immortality and light-speed travel will become available in my lifetime, but I gain a strange feeling of comfort that in 200-300 years time, humans might have further shed their primal instincts of eat, fuck, sleep, repeat. Maybe when this happens, humans will be able to collaborate and make the speculations in this video a reality.

because of causality, the universe we observe is very different to the universe we live in. There may exist many advanced civilisations and it is highly likely that we cannot see them because their light hasn't reached us yet, if for example a civilization 1000 light years away(narrows down the amount of exo planets significantly) chooses today to colonize the galaxy, because of causality we wont see their impact on the universe for 1000 years, and this limitation grows exponentially the further you go and the more exo-planets you include. when a civilization enters the space age era, like ourselves, we can speculate that it may take us a 1000 years to get to the end of the modern or space age era, maybe this is the same for other civilizations and so its highly like that the universe is swarming with thousands of civilizations more advanced than us or like us but we can't see them because of causality.

Everyone is wondering where all the aliens are. But why should there be aliens? A lot of people have the assumption that life is always trying to happen, that as soon as life is possible it will happen. But in reality life is random, just a chemical reaction, so even if all the circumstances were right, the chances are very small. There are so many other random reactions that could take place, would we even recognise life? and even if there is other life, why would it be intelligent? Why is 'intelligence' necessary? The most succsesful life forms are bacteria, virals, single cells, and basic plants. And even of the animals, the sucsesful ones are not intelligent. So why are we assuming that the galaxy should be filled with intelligent civilizations?

I think aliens will be peaceful, if they have the tech to reach us.

I think that if they have the technology to reach us then they will most likely have what they need to live sustainably. I think water recycling systems and sustainable energy sources are easier to come by then warp drives and intergalactic travel. So the whole "strip Earth for resources" bit seems a little unlikely for a civ so advanced.

Also, I believe that violence is rooted in the subconscious survival instincts left in our heads from primitive man. We often forget that over 10,000 years ago we were still basically farmer/hunters in most places. We are not very far removed from an age where violence was necessary for continuing a species. Modern men do not need to fight giant jungle cats or enemy tribes on a daily basis for we have laws and technology to make peaceful lives possible. I think, if we can maintain our current level of technology, to some degree, we will eventually evolve or rather acclimatize, to peace.

I think Quantum Consciousness, Quantum Suicide and Quantum Immortality are the most interesting answers to the Fermi Paradox. It posits that all consciousness (the ability to think, feel and experience anything) is, at it's core, a quantum mechanical phenomenon; it is simply the sum of all the electrical activity in our brains.

The Many Worlds Interpretation of quantum mechanics states that for every quantum state that exists in our universe, all of its infinite number of alternative states exist in an infinite number of parallel universes. But despite being separated by different universes, all of these states are linked by their Wave Function; the sum of all probabilities for a quantum event or state.

If this can scale up to the level of consciousness and if a conscious being were to die in this universe, their consciousness MIGHT instantly separate from this universe and merge with the consciousness of their counterpart in a parallel universe in which they continue to live.

Their body and brain would die in this universe, but their mind would instantaneously merge with that of their still-living "twin" in the other universe, and would essentially be "immortal"; that process could be repeated over and over in which they die, their consciousness keeps jumping and merging with the next adjacent universe, and in the end, they never experience the thing that kills them.

If this were true and a hyper-advanced alien civilization discovered it, they could use it to their advantage by creating something called a "Quantum Suicide Machine." It would be a machine that is programmed to monitor some process or event; if an undesired outcome is met, the machine becomes active and kills them (a gun, bomb, poison, whatever). If a desired outcome is met, the machine stays inactive and they live.

If Quantum Consciousness, Quantum Suicide and Quantum Immortality are real, a hyper-advanced alien race could keep using a Quantum Suicide Machine to keep killing themselves every time something they didn't want happens, and would continuously jump from one universe to the next until their desired outcomes are met. They wouldn't have to work to create a perfect world; they would just have to keep killing themselves over and over again until they woke up in a universe that was just right for them.

The biggest question surrounding the Fermi Paradox is actually more critical than whether there are other Earth like planets or whether the type of lifeforms seen on Earth could develop in another star system. It has to do with the evolution of the type of self conscious life form capable of perceiving the universe in a way that contact with them is even possible.

That is a huge question and as of yet the answer seems to be that the type of life form that we associate with "intelligent" life might be extremely rare. And it's not hard to imagine why. When we look back on the development of the human race it's hard to imagine how that could be replicated on another world. There is prevailing idea in science that self conscious intelligent life is the end goal of evolution. That all ecosystems and life naturally progress to the point that intelligent life must develop. However, I think that is a hopeful idea that we hold onto and might not reflect the realities of the universe.

Just looking at it on a basic level, nothing about evolution or the systems we think governs the evolution of life necessarily dictates that a self conscious organism has to develop or even needs to develop in any given ecosystem. One of the most successful life forms on Earth were the dinosaurs, who dominated the ecosystems of Earth for 160 million years. And in all that time we cannot see any progression towards a more intelligent life form. They had no barriers to develop intelligence and yet they stayed at animal level intelligence for the entirety of there existence. That right there is a big clue that self conscious intelligent is not really necessary in an ecosystem for life to evolve and thrive. Even though we have experienced extreme levels of growth in our population in such a short period of time, the overwhelmingly vast majority of the life forms on this planet are simple bacteria. In the grander scheme of things bacteria and single cell organisms are the dominant life form on Earth. So in that scheme of things intelligence is not truly necessary for life to evolve or flourish in any ecosystem.

Then we get to the issue of the development of our intelligence and the factors that allowed us to expand our scope of knowledge and perceptions to where we can question our very place in the universe and ask "is there anyone out there" If you look at the evolution of the human race you can't but notice just how many incidental and circumstantial factors played huge roles in our ability to grow smarter and exploit our environment and explore our universe. Our stable magnetic field. The position of stars in our night sky. The moon's very existence. The distribution of minerals and metals on the Earth surface. These are just a few of the multitudes of factors that played huge roles in our development of intelligence. So many factors have to be just right to allow for the type of evolution that led us to where we are today. And in reality none of these developments are actually necessary. There is nothing we can see in our evolution that says we couldn't have been stuck in stone age technologies to this day. Or even an earlier form of development. It's just not there.

So in fact if we do ever explore the cosmos I feel we will be largely disappointing with what we find out there. We will find many "Earth like" planets, or at least planets capable of forming the type of organic life that we see in our world. But the complexity of that life with vary wildly from world to world, as each planet's development will strictly dictate how far in evolution that life can progress. I would venture to bet that the vast majority of life in the cosmos never gets beyond the single cell stage. It's the easiest and most robust form of life that can exist. On the rare world we might actually find ecosystems like we see on earth, with varied forms of life in the single and multiple cell variety and may even have animals that we can recognize. But most of them will only have that type of life, because again intelligence is not necessary for life to thrive. It will be the extremely rare planet where we could even find anything that we could associate with self conscious intelligent life. But again unless the factors are just right the ability of that intelligence to develop to the point where they can perceive a universe outside of their world they will never need to develop that type of intelligence to thrive as a species. Just look at our history as a species. The human race manage to migrate and populate every continent on earth long before civilization develop. In fact several earlier hominid species managed to do it as well and we an be sure they are not the type of "intelligent" life we are looking for. So when we do find the rare planet with life forms we would consider "intelligent" they may be locked in a level of development that prevents them from exploring the universe and asking the type of questions we do. There would be no need to if they are a successful species living in tune with the ecosystem. So there may only be a small number of planets were intelligent life exist, but most of those life forms never develop the sophisticate civilizations we see on Earth. We may in fact be the only type of life form in our galaxy even capable of exploring the universe. Maybe every galaxy out there only holds one or two planets where such a thing arises. And just accounting for the vastness of our own galaxy the chances that we are anywhere near a neighboring life form like that is extremely rare.

Then you get into the final problem about relative timelines and parallel development. For all we know several intelligent life forms have existed in the galaxy over the billions of years but rarely do more than one exist at the same time and never are they near enough to each other to make contact possible.

Just my 2 cents, I hate to be pessimistic about the prospect of finding intelligent life but that's how I see it.

I'm just throwing this out there...
Lifeforms are just walking bags of DNA naturally mutating to settle into whatever environment happens to be shaping it at that moment. DNA has as much mind of it's own as cold air does settling into a warm room.
This intelligence we have is just one naturally occurring "strategy" that has allowed our particular combination of DNA (Human) to survive pretty well for some time now in a completely different way than any other lifeforms that we know of. Our Human DNA is no longer responsive to the whims of the environment, through us, it can now shape it's own environment.
But like I said, DNA has no intelligence of it's own, this combination just happens to be one of trillions of DNA sequences possible but also one that happens to be working pretty good for the moment in regards to survival.
Consider all those trillions of possible sequences and all the billions of different lifeforms that have existed on our planet so far and contrast that with our unique Human abilities and the relatively short amount of time we've existed and you might appreciate why there's only one of us, anywhere.

Consider this. We live on a prison planet. We are the descendants of the Galaxy's undesirable riff-raff.
My theory starts long ago. As the population of the galaxy increased it was no longer viable to detain prisoners in a building. What was needed was an entire planet. So, the many races of a great space faring community gathered up all these prisoners and dropped them on a prison planet, Earth.
Think about it. Humans and apes supposedly have a common ancestor yet are we supposed to believe that out of this evolution we get not one but many different races of intelligent beings?

And lastly, the UFO sightings that people see all over the planet going back at least 100 years and more, are easily explained.
These UFO's are prison guards. Think about it. If aliens decided to build a space ship and fly around the universe until they come across intelligent life why don't they communicate with us? I've been thinking about the Fermi Paradox for a while and I have come up with a variation on the zoo hypothesis.

Perhaps one or more civilizations has/have formed that is/are either directly or indirectly blocking electronic signals and probes from reaching our solar system. All it would take is for just one technologically advanced alien species to achieve this, and it vastly simplifies the issues of the zoo hypothesis (Wouldn't at least some aliens initiate contact? Does the Prime Directive apply to all alien cultures?).

Of course this opens up the possibility that there is an arbiter of our galaxy and maybe even of our entire Universe. If this is true, then we are possibly a part of a massive artificial selection process. The species that don't meet the standards of this arbiter are removed from the process and cut off from outside contact. Perhaps one day we will meet the arbiter's standards, perhaps we have already failed the test. I admit that I have no idea what the possible motivation for this would be, but I still believe that this is the most likely solution that doesn't involve a Rare Earth hypothesis.
The thought that humans might be the First Ones is enchanting and terrifying at the same time. With great power comes great responsibility ... and I don't see much of the latter around.

If we scale the age of the Milky Way to a 24 hour period beginning at midnight, Earth wasn't formed for 15 hours, 40 minutes (3:40 pm).
Emergence of microbial life: ~ 5:00 pm
Multi-cellular life: ~ 11:00 pm
Dinosaur extinction: ~ 11:52:45 pm
Earliest hominid ancestors first appeared just 30 seconds ago: ~ 11:59:30 pm
Our species emerged just 1.3 seconds ago: ~ 11:59:58.7 pm
Civilization emerged only 0.07 seconds ago: ~ 11:59:59.93 pm
The first telescope was invented 0.00267 seconds ago: ~ 11:59:59.99733 pm
The moon landing happened 0.00031 seconds ago: ~ 11:59:59.99969 pm

On this scale, civilization emerged less than a blink of an eye ago. Out of the course of an entire day, our species managed to technologically evolve from simple tools, buildings made of mud, and learning agriculture, to satellite systems & exploration vehicles & robots all over the solar system, all during the final blink of an eye, although life on the planet has been around for 7 hours!

What happened? Why us? I don't really buy into the Fermi paradox, because there really isn't one. Upon what grounds can anyone assume that the emergence of civilized life is inevitable, let alone the ability to spread around the cosmos? It's not as if we can look back on to Earth's history and see a record of past civilizations across several different species or anything. It's just us; we are the only example of civilization we have. Civilization, as far as anyone can tell, is highly unusual to say the least, and completely unique to be accurate.

Where is this rapidly evolving trend of technology appear to be taking us? Overpopulation, climate change, depletion of resources, and destruction of natural habitat. We are the cause of Earth's sixth global mass extinction event, and we will also become victims of it. Maybe our technology will pull us through, but the fact is we depend on the survivability of thousands & thousands of other species as well.

If the emergence of human civilization & technology is a typical example of how it develops in other places around the universe, then there is no paradox. Civilization merely wipes itself out in a blink of an eye. The idea that another civilization evolved communicating technology precisely during the last 2 milliseconds along with us is a hell of a stretch, and to take the idea further, and expect to make contact with (or simply discover) each other during the last 300 microseconds is totally absurd.

I always thought this was a question speculated on by cosmologists and physicists, that would have been more appropriately addressed to evolutionary biologists. I'm not an evolutionary biologist, but I get the feeling that a lot of important things are swept under the rug here. For example: Why is it inevitable that at least one evolutionary line should lead to "intelligence?" What are the factors that need to be in place for an organism to develop a capacity for abstract thoughts, self-awareness, and reasoning? Or opposable thumbs, so it can manipulate its environment? Or curiosity, so it will continue to do so even without immediate gain? For collective learning, so that information can be passed down and built on? There's so much that has to go on for an organism to reach a state where it can massively manipulate its environment like we do. When you look at our history, if it weren't for several extinction events, life would have stalled. I think the chances of life getting to a state like ours are way, way smaller than the cosmologists asking these questions would think, and it's not so much a "Paradox" as much as it is wishful thinking.

I believe that life is everywhere, not just on planets we consider to be habitable, but quite literally everywhere throughout the universe.  I think it exists on planets with extreme environments, Earthlike planets, comets, asteroids, and even some hardy lifeforms living and thriving in deep space itself..  This being said, I think the Fermi Paradox has more to do with the assumption that intelligent life is inevitable, which I don't believe it is.  Our own intelligence had arisen out of some very unique circumstances.  For billions of years life evolved on this planet and thrived without the need for intelligence such as ours, and to be honest our own particular brand of intelligence seems to be detrimental to the planet and the other species inhabiting it.  We humans are biased in believing that we are in some way experiencing a normal phase of evolution, when we may actually be an accidental exception to the normal rules of planetary evolution.

1. The speed of light more than just makes it difficult to travel through the cosmos, but also prevents us from seeing the progress being made. It is likely we don't have the insight to see or even comprehend our alien friends. Just look at the creatures of the ocean depths. Can your eyes distinguish their bodies from the surroundings?

2. A Great Filter may prevent life from reaching a very technological stage, making technological entities a rarity... though that may open the possibility that most aliens will be more like Venom than Superman, more like bacteria than macroscopic bodies. Combined with the previous problem, that means we're left unable to find any nearby aliens while the more advanced ones are out of sight.

3. For extragalactic aliens, there may be internal competition. Not only would they be slowed by other interstellar entities, but they'd be facing internal resistance. Maintaining a cohesive galactic empire isn't easy. Cohesion, even with some kind of instantaneous communication device, may be challenged by temporal distortions. A unifying language across the empire would end up useless when everyone's clocks flow too differently.

4. Our aliens may ascend to a higher dimension long before reaching the nearest planet, having become part of an intelligence singularity so fast that they end up creating their own bubble universe. At this point, any sufficiently advanced alien civilization would be indistinguishable from being dead. Of course, we're looking for aliens, not gods.
