The Fermi paradox is bs. So many things are assumed just to make this point that the concept is completely nonsense.

There are some obvious reasons that aliens would never be able to contact us indirectly.

One- physics. No matter how good the aliens technology is, there is no hope of radio signals making it here from even a few million light years away. Why? Because as light travels it loses energy. This is true for the entire electromagnetic spectrum. The space between far distant places like between galaxies is expanding which causes the light waves to lose energy as they travel across that space and the waves elongate. This is why we use radial velocity to see how stars and other objects that are far away move. As the light loses energy it shifts more and more to low energy levels- ie. blue to red and red to infrared and so on. Radio waves are near the bottom of the electromagnetic range when it comes to energy levels. Radio contact is impossible because in order to travel to 99.99999% of the universe, the radio waves would disparate long before they got there.

Next, to send something with mass (creature or machine, etc.) to most of the universe would take much longer than how many light years are between the two destinations. Keep in mind- nothing with mass can accelerate to light speed thanks to relativity. Accelerating anything with mass even near light speed would require such a massive amount of energy that the gravitational affects (tidal forces) alone would destroy and spagettify the atoms of the object trying to be sent.

Not to mention the fact that no material has a long enough half life to survive a hunted million +year trip to another galaxy with enough structural integrity to still function.

Then there is the energy consumption issues and so on and so forth.

Also, the statistics are terribly wrong here. A planet doesn't have to be earth like for life to survive on it. Nor does the star have to be sun like. Nor does the planet have to be in the sun's Goldielox zone. Gravity and rotation and hydrostatic equilibrium stability as a million other factors come into play. Let alone the radiation issues.

There may be hundreds of billions of times more livable planets out there or maybe only tens of millions. We don't know.

Also, how are we to assume life evolves along a similar path to ours over any time period. Evolution is strongly tied to the environmental pressures of the environment of the life in question.

Maybe we're at the hight of intelligence or mate we are an oddball of life in the universe and most life is smarter than us or most life doesn't care about social interaction or something totally different.

These are only the smallest of the problems that there are with discovering life in the universe.

Although statistically impossible to nail down, it seems very likely that intelligent life exists elsewhere in the universe but it seems extremely unlikely that contact will ever come.

The Big Bang (or inflation etc.) would have occurred in the centre of this universe. Given that the universe is ~13.8 billion years old, for the matter to get 45,000,000,000 light years away from the epicentre in 13.8 billion years, it must have been travelling many times the speed of light.

It's a fascinating paradox.  But as one tries to resolve certain variables in Drakes's equation, some logical perspective is helpful.  The idea of inter-stellar civilizations is completely hypothetical, especially given the fact that exceeding the speed of light in travel is also completely hypothetical.  What remains, logically?  Other civilizations roughly equal to ours are simply too far away for communication -- or, in the scope of billions of years, such civilizations have simply died out before our recent ability to send signals was developed.  Which leads us to what I think is the most compelling, and logical, version of the theory: the great Filter.  Development of life on earth suggests it is NOT easy, or necessarily inevitable.  Survival is also difficult in a hostile universe.  Of course the Filter may be ahead of us, and out historical record as a super-predator species does not bode well in that respect

A few thoughts on this matter:
Why would a sentent species ever colonise something outside it's home planet?
In our history we had one period of time when colonising or at least exploring something extraterrestrial was considered outside of economical means... but that also involved heavy political rivalry of two groups trying to "be the first there". And eventually this rivalry died out.

Most of modern extraterrestrial activity nowadays revolves around economical gains (be it fast data transit through communication sattelites, or possible H3-excavations on the moon) or sientific research.

Colonising other planets for simple "preserving of species" is currently out of question. Like it would probably be good to have some place where people would still live if earth goes boom, but with current level of expenses this colonisation would take... not worth it.
After all, overstressing out present resources to get this "second home" might really endanger our current home. Especially if you take there is no guarantee colonisation would be successful.

Dealing with overpopulation by the means of colonisation is something often mentioned in sience fiction... but then again - Wars seem to deal with excess population quite effectively and cheaply. Grim as it may sound I belive humanity will rather kill half of itself and keep all Earth resources to itself, rather then spend half of resources to send some people away.

The only remaining reason for colonisation is - getting access to more resources. Let's face it - this is actually why humanity ever did colonisation. In 99% of times it did end up in colony declaing independance when it gets developed enough, but in the original idea it was always sending resources to metropoly. So I expect us (and all species with similar psychology) to use this reason for colonisation.
And unless you have FTL propulsion, such interstellar colonisation is out of question. No point in spending resources on colony ship if the closes time it can bring profit back is like in 200 years, no one would even invest in this.
So there are two possibilities:
1) FTL is not possible. Like never ever. This mean that all civilisations are locked in type II. Never capable of setting colonies outside of their home system.
2) There are FTL civilisations out there... but they are not using radiowaves for communication. At least not in interstellar range. Why would you sent a message by radio, when you can send an FTL courier that will bring your message faster? Or if they have FTL propultion, they are as likely to have FTL communication as well.

PS: One other reasons for colonisation I missed, and only now remembered:
"Brave new worlds" - let's call it like this. It is a lot like "dealing with extra population" but might occur even if there is no population problems, but instead there are many people who are not content with their present residence, for cultural, political of economical means. Like refugees that are willing to venture to some place - be it even the other planet - in bare hopes that life there would be better than at home.
This is also a possibility, but honestly - as our technological level increases - more and more people are being content with their life. As our societies and political systems evolve, less people are feeling pressured to leave... So likely by the time we hit the technology capable of bringing us to the stars, there will be not enough people willing to leave comforts of our home planet and venture into wilderness. Probably people would not be able to survive out of civilisation by then. Like present-day city dwellers are quite likely to die if they are placed in some wild and harsh enviroment, like desert, or jungle.

Earth isn't special for its resources. All elements plentiful or rare on earth can be found on lots of other planets in systems whose matter has at least once gone through a supernova, in order to generate all the interesting heavy elements.

Earth is special for being in the habitable zone of a stable star and in a configuration of other celestial bodies keeping away most disturbances. Magnetic field and tectonic activity appear to be good for life as well. Studying all this would be as interesting for alien exobiologists as it would be for us to study their worlds. Earth's wealth certainly lies in its biology, and while it may not be unique in having some form of life, the combination of all DNA on earth is certainly unique.

Other than that, we can speculate but until we get a clear sign, we are in the dark. At least we aren't burning those any more who dare to suggest there's life outside our little planet.

Our logic would have to apply to them (the basic mechanics at least, 2+2=4 on Earth, as well as Mars, the Andromeda Galaxy, in a black hole, at the start of the Big Bang, a neutron star, etc.) because we share a universe.  If you have a correct system and plug information into that system then the output will be logical and correct.  If there are intelligent civilizations we can deduce that they'd discover the same laws given the universality of math.  

Specifics however may be a different story.  They may lack empathy, be flagrantly sociopathic, run the other animals on their planet to extinction to kill off the competition for resources, radically different (within the context of being possible for life of course so we aren't talking gas giants or Venus like planets here) environments and circumstances leading them to evolve different psychologies, may be more cooperative than humans, different biologies leading to different needs, etc.  However, they would still need to eat, survive, and replicate and try finding the optimal ways of doing so, but optimal for them would be different than for humans as our respective planets would obviously be different.

The Fermi Paradox is one depressing refutation against alien visitation.  You also have the speed of light limit.  To go near light speed you need to get the equivalent energy of billions of tons of fuel to get just one pound to reach 99.9999% light speed.  So not only is it ludicrously expensive and wasteful to go that fast, but still impractically slow.

It is not very likely that an advanced alien civilization would seek to take or use Earth's (or the solar system's) resources.  There is not anything unique here and we are pretty isolated out here.  It would be like driving 3000 miles to a gas station when you have a gas station 1 mile from your home.  You use up immense resources of energy, time, and greatly increase your risk for no useful reason. 

There are some good reasons to believe that a species risk of extinction decreases tremendously (to near zero) if it can achieve interstellar colonization.  Most of the risk to an advanced species is related to severe damage to its home planet / ecosystem.  If such an event no longer renders a species extinct, it is nearly impossible for extinction to occur.  It would require multiple near simultaneous disasters on multiple planets, a hostile force trying to kill everyone, or the heat death of the universe for example.

I think that the vast distance of space keeps life from getting too far form it's star. We need an entire biosphere to support us. If we find another Earth like planet, it'll probably be living in a version of Earth like the Archean or the Protozoic, where it's just microbes in the sea and an atmosphere with too little oxygen or perhaps made of methane. Most of Earth's history, it looked like that and only for about 13% of Earth's history, has complex multicellular life been present.

So if you arrive at such a planet, you will need to terraform it, but adding in all the microbes and waiting for them to colonize the planet and bring about an oxygen based atmosphere. (1) Then you need to add in filter feeders like sponges and algae like kelp to speed the process. Sponges would help spread oxygen below the surface layer, aiding the spread of eukaryotic life to the lower levels. After oxygenizing it, you need to warm the planet up, as the process of oxygenizing an atmosphere, cools the planet down as carbon gets locked away in microbial mats (2). Earth had to fight off many ice ages and/or snowball earths every time oxygen levels jumped and continental drift was the saving grace that subducted trapped carbon and released it via volcanoes. If the world is warmed, photosynthesis can happen faster and flooded continents provides mineralization and shallow seas for life.

To prevent a cooling, a planet needs burrowers to kill off the microbial mats (3) on the sea floor and filter feeders to control photosynthetic microbes and detritivores to recycle the dead matter faster. Coral reefs, which exist in sunny warm areas with low nutrients, need to be developed to produce oxygen. The coral filter feed desperately needed nutrients and hands it off to the algae growing on it and they share resources with each other. A coral reef has more tiering than a microbial mat and thus is more effective at making oxygen and their skeletons grow and create larger reefs and more photosynthesis opportunities. But the world might get too warm so it has to be cooled (4) so more predators need to be introduced (starfish, nautilus, crabs, and when more oxygen arrives, fish).

Our goal is to get enough oxygen to make an ozone so life can move to land. Then you need to get mosses and the associated microorganisms onto the wetlands to finish oxygenation (5). Then we need to get fungi to break down the rocky surfaces for the woody plants and ferns that will follow. We have to start with conifers and ferns, since insects don't exist to pollinate flowering plants. Then the trees will ultimately break into new soils and drop the nutrients when it dies and thus be washed into the rivers, changing ocean chemistry and fueling an algae bloom (6) which is deadly to the ocean life you introduced. Then you need to introduce fungi and bacteria to break down dead trees, or else the carbon gets locked up and the Earth cools down (7) and the trapped carbon could trigger a later extinction if released later all at once (8). Then you could introduce the rest of the parts, such as flowering plants, insects, birds, mammals, etc, to make it a viable world.

This list of conditions is close to the order of events and life earth went through to create a biosphere that supports. Each number represents an extinction that happened on earth when that change happened and earth always bounced back and moved forward, but each one, could have gone wrong and ended development of complex life before intelligent life could arrive. 

So, for an alien species to travel far, and introduce species to build a biosphere on another planet, will take time and require bringing all these stock species and keeping them alive. And we no longer have species like trilobites that can serve as an effective detritivore in lower oxygen conditions and we only one a few nautilus species left and they might not even know how to be predators in low oxygen conditions anymore.

So that bears the question, if we can't terraform, can we survive in indoor colonies on a planet without a biosphere supporting us for a long period of time? This was kind of a brain exercise to me, but it explains the Fermi Paradox perhaps a bit better, by both explaining the trials Earth had to go through, and the difficulty of truly inhabiting new planets.

I like the idea that we are near the end of discovering what is possible for generation of energy and propulsion because so far, science suggests that it is so. It could be that 1/10,000 planets manages to develop life because we do actually have a lot of requirements and maybe 2/10^9 of those within 10,000 light years of each other has "intelligent" life on it at any given time. Then, within that extremely sparse population, none of them come up with anything substantially better than petroleum or solar panels or neuclear fission. So, they just never have enough energy that their population also decides to dedicate to the search for other life in the universe to ever come anywhere near finding it. Maybe 100 years from now, we won't have all of this energy, massive wars will destroy all civilizations (like Mad Max) and when things settle down, we'll have a small population that concerns itself with survival and all of this exploration stuff is put aside. I hope not, but it could just be that way for every civilization that develops anywhere. What if it's essentially a mechanism of nature that only beings that will do that will ever evolve intelligence in the first place?

I see the chief problem with life being the competition for resources. To suceed, a life form is programmed to find the resources it needs to survive and multiply. This will eventually bring it into competition with other life forms  that require the same resources (or are in the way of getting them). Competition brings losers and in an enclosed system (a planet) eventually resources dwindle.
At the end of the day, life is just borrowed order and entropy is the master of all.

To really suceed, a life form has to get the technology to get off the planet (like a virus finding a new host.) or change the way they operate (against their programming) and self limit reproduction and live symbiotically and beneficiently with each other and their resources.

Unfortunately, I don't see many life forms that are thinking that far forward and most of them seem happy enough just making sure they have their needs covered in the short to medium term, without thinking eventually their planet won't support them. Eventually the planet doesn't support them and they'll die off. Different life forms become the tip of the pyramid and the cycle begins anew.

Should you try to be a long term thinker (as an individual or species), short to medium term thinkers will be already living in mansions and flying their jets around to make bigger and more destructive deals with their fellow short to medium term thinking friends and ruin your plans.

I believe that any aliens that are advanced enough to get into space would also be wise and peaceful. Therefore, they would not want to interfere in our affairs and potentially cause havoc and chaos. Just imagine all the possible riots or chaos that might occur on Earth if people found out that aliens were real. So, if aliens are peaceful, they simply wouldn't come here, being afraid that it might unduly affect our development. This is a amazing video, but it misses out on a couple key ideas.

1. It takes a lllooonngg time for stuff to evolve (according to what we know), and very very basic life has existed for around 4.5/16 of the, theoretical, Big Bang. Based off of this, and where we are know, one can infer that it takes awhile for the conditions of life to appear, and unless a planet existed quite a bit before ours they would probably not be close to, or further along technologically.

2. Evolution and how it might work on intelligence. Humans as a smart species (compared to any other animals) didn't get this way by chance, we got this way by fighting each other. A monkey (for example) finds a stick and attacks another monkey with it (again, for example), other monkeys see this and learn from it, a monkey sees a rock fall and kill another monkey, learns from this and starts throwing rocks. Onward, and onward this goes to a period of "sentience." (Pause for intake of breath) To play back on the original idea, this is just another factor that would affect/effect (too lazy to look up the difference between the affect/effect) whether or not they would be even close to our level.
A. There is even another factor to this! It also depends upon what a animals behavior might be. Aggressive or Neutral? Some animal might learn to throwing of rocks, but just not ever care about it or use it. This factor could be played upon in insane amounts of difference. A couple of these factors could be added to the Drake Equation.

3. Random animal and plant life that just doesn't give crap whether or not we die or find and harvest/train them.

4. Not really related, but a idea all the same. A matrix type theory, where we are all computer programs running on the Big 42's computer.

[long text ahead] I don't man, if you want to read, this is my opinion: that we are way too young in this universe. Maybe there was a spaceship or something on Earth way before there was any form of life on it. They saw an empty place, moved on. I mean yes, I belive there is some form of life in the universe besides us. If the universe is infinite as we think it is, and if the universe is as old as we think it is, then be sure there is some form of life somewhere. Maybe bacterias, maybe robots... or maybe something that we don't have a word to name it yet, some kind of weird fucker that eats babies for dinner.

And sure, if they are older and way more advanced, maybe they discovered a way to travel faster than the speed of light. The speed of light may be the fastest thing in our law of physics, but think about it for a second. What if our laws of physics don't apply to them. And they have discovered their own laws that, in their circumstances, work and act way differently. Maybe the speed of light is their legal speed to travel between their home planets and they can go way much faster. Think on something that works based on tachyons, and boom = faster than the speed of light. We think we know a lot about physics but 99% of the physics we know applies here, on Earth. Other planet maybe have different gravity, different resistance etc. So with that kind of technology they can travel really fast, making the empty parts of the universe feel like a 10 hour drive on the highway.

Thing is altho I belive there is someone, somewhere, I don't belive we are going to find out. Humans will die as a species and we won't meet the other species from the universe. IF ... the universe is infinite, then there's a really high chance that they are way, way far away. So it would take millions of years for them to get to us, even with a technology that we cannnot imagine, like I've said above. Because you know...infinity is... infinite.

We will die alone. And maybe... that's better.

I can hardly tell you how much I enjoy your videos! It is clear that we do not come from the same worldview, yet you never come across as hostile or bullying, but as one who is only seeking to explain complex processes or ideas in the most effective way possible. I would probably not agree with you that mutations have been shown to produce positive results for a species, or that pure unguided chance could give rise to the multiple levels of interlocking machinery required for even the simplest living thing, yet your depiction of evolutionary processes is flawless. When considering the relativity of time, The Fermi Paradox makes much more sense than it initially seems. It would be really easy for other civilizations to miss each other in the universe due to their varying perspectives in time and the vast distances between them. Consider for example that Ocean planet on Interstellar and all the years that passed by on Earth while being just a few hours from the perspective of McConaughey (Cooper) and Hathaway (Brand). Just imagine being on such a planet for a year. The entire human civilization could flicker in and out before one knew it even existed. Then considering how long it takes even for light to travel the distances in space, it would be very difficult to pinpoint that another civilization exists at the exact same time as you. Since we are constantly looking into the past, it could be thousands of years in the future by the time another civilization became aware of our present and vise versa.

I think this series seriously jumped the shark.  I thought this was about science, but instead, it is about fantasies with no way to prove anything.  But if you want one more idea as to why we haven't found other life (and they haven't found us), it is this...  Maybe these "Type 1, 2, and 3" Civilizations are bunk, just like Dragon Ball Z power levels.  Maybe there is no way to become even a Type 1 civilization, and every civilization which has tried to control their entire planet has ended up destroying their own civilization.  What if humans, in the technological sense, grew up, exercised, and then became body builders.  But we THINK that if we continue into the future, we will become Goku and fire kamehamehas or like Piccolo and Vegeta, blow up moons and planets with ki blasts.  But maybe, just maybe, we are not that far off from our peak.  Maybe our gluttonous energy needs now are like a body builder on steroids who is already in his 30s.  We're being pumped up even past what we would naturally get, and it is all downhill from here (or from 100 years hence...whenever our peak is).  One thing characterizing humanity is hubris.  Thinking that we will control the galaxy one day or meet beings who do is just one more example, not too far removed from thinking that the sun revolves around is.  Maybe, just maybe, we ain't going too far.  Compare jet airplanes from 50 years ago to jet airplanes today.  There is about no difference, including no increase in speed...over 50 years!  50 years before that, the Wright Brothers were taking off.  If you were in 1957 and saw a new Boeing 707 that could cruise at 570 mph (917 kph) and compared them to the Wright Brothers from a half-century prior, and then thought of what a half-century in the future would hold, you would not imagine a Boeing 787 with a top speed of 593 mph (954 kph), would you?  I would say to not stop doing research.  Research is important, and it can lead to many things that might come as a surprise (like the internet did, when we instead thought that we'd have robot servants), but let's not fool ourselves into thinking that its fruits will be endless.  I don't think we'll ever get to "Type 1", and whoever thought of "Type 3" is a complete moron who should not even be quoted, any more than than someone who believes in unproven supernatural phenomena.

At 1:37 you propose that it may be common for an interstellar-capable species to settle a few additional solar systems and then die out.  I show in my paper on the Fermi Paradox that this explanation is highly unlikely.  The chance of multiple independent societies dying out is a binomial probability of the number of settlements.  The more locales settled, the greater the chance of survival.  A species that establishes even a handful of independent settlements is essentially immortal.  And yes, they would be independent (free of causal powers and effects from one another).  I explain that as well in the same paper.

Links to the paper:

http://arxiv.org/abs/1111.6131

http://www.keithwiley.com/mindRamblings/fermiParadox.shtml

http://hplusmagazine.com/2014/11/18/fermi-paradox-self-replicating-probes-interstellar-transportation-bandwidth

It seems like there is a huge amount of assumption here.  What if there are plenty of alien life forms out there that are intelligent and none are as advanced as we are?  Or, perhaps none of these life forms have had any need to develop complex communication technology.  In this case, they may have other technologies that are centuries past ours, but they have no use for radio.  Perhaps, they have technology that is so alien to us we can't even conceive their purpose.  Perhaps, they live on a scale of time or size that we cannot perceive.  It seems to me that saying what is likely, or even more efficient for an alien culture mostly guess work based on one unrelated data point.

There is a complete flaw in this argument, about how an alien civilization might not be able to understand us more than a squirrel, and it's very simple.  Any alien civilization would look to see if we were a fact based society or not.  If we were not a fact based society, then at a certain level of technological advancement, we would be deemed a threat, a civilization that could not be trusted.  No attempt to communicate with us would ever be made, and we would likely be wiped out purposely.  You see this is the premise of 2001 A Space Odyssey.  No one realizes this, because the intro that was only seen at the premiere of the movie was cut (there is a book about the movie that explains this whole intro that was cut and never spoken of again, "The Making of Kubrick's 2001" it is a rare book) and never seen again.  Basically theoretical scientists explain, from all over the world, that the quickest way to explore the universe would be to send out an advanced computer to a planet, that would duplicate itself, and send out 10 more to other planets, and so on.  That the speed of exploring the universe would increase exponentially, as they replicated and were sent out.  This is the "obelisk" in 2001.  This is actually what the theory of levels of space civilizations, 0,1,2, and 3, that your whole discussion is based on, that I believe are based off of Michio Kaku, who took this idea directly from these scientists.  These obelisks would sit and wait, and observe, they might even help civilizations (unknowingly to us) to achieve sentience or certain understandings.  Whether or not you understand a civilization's culture, you can understand if they are based on fact.  If they lie, and cheat, and murder their own, they are likely not based on fact, and are self-destructive.  Which in turn means, after reaching a certain level of advancement, that in fact they would destroy us naturally for their own safety.  The other argument I hear to dispute that is, well they probably aren't peaceful, they're probably just like us.  In which case you would never want to meet them, because they would conquer us, treat us like pets, and do as they chose with us.  We would never be seen as equals.  We would make big pets.

I think a Matrioshka Brain would be a practical solution to this. Sustaining an interstellar civilization and all the resources that would require would be a bit ridiculous when all a Matrioshka Brain would need is power which could easily be supplied by a star for as you said trillions of years. A very powerful quantum computer may provide the ability to do such a thing aswell as being able to potentially extend our perception of time to stretch those trillions of years we'd already have. A virtual environment could be a lot more convenient and open up the possibility for people to experience things that would be impossible or absurdly difficult in reality.

Also to be able to start progressing in technology you don't need to be incredibly intelligent or have the entire species able to invent new tools. You'd only need a percentage of the population to be able to exploit their environment to their advantage and make things easier for them, and then you would start progressing. That's why now we have some people capable of understanding the mechanics of an atom, with others who think i'd be a good idea to use nuclear weapons. As for alien species, they would probably have the same story at least until their technology allowed them to surpass that, and social interaction is a key part of civilization so empathy might be a necessary evolved trait for a society. In that case I think that aliens even if they were more intelligent than us would just leave us alone. In a universe as big as ours an offensive strategy is a bit crazy so If we ever were a threat anyway defending would be more practical. Home field advantage is amplified significantly when you have to transport supplies light years. A "grey goo" weapon in the universe that was automated might work but again would require an alien civilization to be unsympathetic or be the biggest act of terrorism the universe has ever known.

Our history has shown technological progress can happen very quickly and is getting faster, so any communication with aliens would either be with something incomprehensibly more advanced than us or far behind us, although at this stage the former is much more likely. The civilization that's less advanced would be the only one to benefit and as they would likely blow them selves up somehow if they were clued into the advanced technology too quickly assuming that those two civilizations could communicate which would be very hard, natural progression would be safer anyway. Communication would probably be impractical and any interaction with other life might just be out of curiosity.

All that being said I don't know, just some thoughts.

One thing I consistently see overlooked in Fermi paradox discussions is the idea that maybe we're just one of the first species to be capable of space exploration.

Every time I hear people talk about ancient galactic empires it bothers me because people neglect the fact that technological development basically requires certain heavy elements (like iron, copper, platinum, etc.) Which are incredibly rare in the universe and were not present at all for the first several billions of years.

Organic molecules and (simple) life may be as old as the first carbon atoms, but technologically advanced life depends on more recent elements that took a very long time for stars to forge.

My answer to the Fermi paradox is that we're simply the first.

It is possible to travel faster than the speed of light without violating the laws of physics. It's called a warp drive. I think there are many (more) important arguments missing. For example:
A species that managed space flight probably has managed birth control. Even if it had other planets to settle to, its influence may be limited due to demographics.

OK, I think we are finished with the Fermi Paradox for now – there is enough content for a third video where we could talk about the solutions that we left out. Do you want this video to exist? (we might do it in 2016) If you go to our (still pretty empty) subreddit (www.reddit.com/r/kurzgesagt), there will be discussion of future topics – for example people there was a survey two months ago where people decided between the Fermi Paradox and Dark Energy. The first survey was on Twitter, in the future those will be held on reddit.
